Neil Duncan-Jordan, of the National Pensioners Convention, who organised the protest, said: “This is a cut to pensioner benefits by the Government, but the BBC is going to take the blame.   Millions rely on the TV as their main source of companionship and pensioner poverty is rising.” Caroline Abrahams, charity director at Age UK, added: “There are .million people aged over  in the UK, one in two of whom are disabled and one in four of whom view the television as their main form of companionship. “For many others, including those who are chronically lonely or immobile, we know that TV is a precious window onto the world.   “There are also signicant numbers of older people living on very low incomes who would genuinely struggle to pay a licence fee so we hope those who are able to will show their support next week on  March. “The Government should stop hiding behind the BBC and accept responsibility for continuing to fund free TV licences for the over-s”.The protest is at  Parliament St, at midday on Thursday.

title: health secretary matt hancock i
story: NewsHealth Secretary Matt Hancock: I would donate my kids organs to save livesEXCLUSIVE: The Conservative minister, who has three children, is joining the Mirror in leading a national conversation to bring about a cultural sht so organ donation is seen as the normal thing to doShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  MAR NewsMr Hancock, here with his we Martha, called on other families to discuss donation so they are preparedtragedy strikes"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is one of the most dficult discussions he has had with his family.But Health Secretary Matt Hancock knows that speaking about donating his children’s organs in the event of a tragedy is the right thing to do. Now the minister, who has three children, is joining the Mirror in leading a national conversation to bring about a cultural sht so organ donation is seen as the normal thing to do.Last month, the Mirror-backed law to change to an opt-out system – where consent to donate organs is assumed – cleared its final hurdle in Parliament. In an exclusive interview at the launch of an NHS drive to train medics to speak to bereaved relatives about donation, he urged families to have the discussion so they are preparedthe worst happens.  Mr Hancock,  – who is tipped as a potential future Tory leader – has a -year-old daughter and two sons, aged  and five. Askedhe would donate his children’s organstragedy struck, Mr Hancock told the Mirror: “Yes, of course. It seems it’s the least you can do. It’s a no-brainer because in the event of a tragedy, the tragedy has happened already. What you can do is salvage a little and help stop others from going through the same tragedy. “For me, this is personal. I’ve seen the anguish and the turnaround in the le of not only the child but their whole family when an organ is made available.”  Mr Hancock explained that his son Ferdie’s best friend had a transplant after being born with a defect where the partition meant to separate the heart into four chambers had not developed. Oliver Flint, , was told in  that he would die without a new heart. He got a donor organ in November . Mr Hancock said: “I care deeply that we get as many donors as possible. “Not least because the child of a close personal friend’s le was saved by the donation of a heart. I have lived with this friend through the anguish of waiting for a donation as their child got weaker and weaker, and I’ve seen the amazing turnaround when the donation happened.  “These donations come from tragedies, but at least talking to the parents of donor children you see the real positives that can be brought out of such tragedy.” Mr Hancock lives with his we, Martha, who is an osteopath, in Little Thurlow in his West Suffolk constituency. He said: “My we and I were both on the register before we met. “With our children, it has become a live issue because of what happened to my son. “We have seen just how important it is that the donations are made. We know the value of being on the register because we have lived through it with our friends. “People talk about the dficult conversations, but the truly awful conversation is the one when a doctor needs to say to parents that their child isn’t going to survive. The conversation about whether their organs are donated is much easier.  “It is heartbreaking that hundreds of very ill children and babies are waiting for an organ right now, and that last year  families went through the unimaginable pain of losing a child while they are waiting for a le-saving organ.” He added: “I completely understand how dficult it is to even contemplate losing a child, let alone think about what happens afterwards. But we must not shy away from this dficult, and potentially le-saving, conversation. Hundreds of young lives were saved last year because of the selfless actions of  families. “To allow your child to live on through saving the lives of others might bring some comfort in a terrible moment.”  After a three-year campaign by the Mirror, a change to donation law was last week confirmed by the House of Lords. The new opt-out system will assume everyone consents to be a donor unless they state otherwise. The Organ Donation Bill will get royal assent and become official this month. It could come in to force before the end of the year. The law will be named Max And Keira’s Law after campaigning heart transplant recipient Max Johnson, , and his donor, Keira Ball, nine. Mr Hancock said: “This is the piece of legislation I’m most proud of since I’ve become Health Secretary. I’m determined to turn it from law in to action as soon as possible.” Dr John Chisholm, British Medical Association ethics chairman, said: “It is very welcome to see the Health Secretary has given his support to this important campaign, which focuses on improving organ donation rates for children.”

title: stop asking women can until
story: NewsopinionStop asking uswomen can have it all until you ask men the same questionIn honour of International Women’s Day, we’ve asked one of our favourite Labour MPs, Jess Phillips, to guest write our First Things First column in Notebook Magazine...ShareByJess Phillips:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionJess says its a given women should be able to have it all "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI get asked all the timeI think that my generation of women can have it all. The question itself is infuriating because what they mean is can a woman have a job, a partner and a family. Having it all seems a pretty low bar. When I was a little girl I dreamed of being a leader, an explorer, or seeing the world and feeling every emotion in bright technicolour. Having it all for a woman is essentially having exactly what men have always expected as the norm. It is pretty basic.   That said, I do recognise for women today we have better opportunities than my mum had. Generations of feminists have fought for better childcare options, equal pay and services to protect women from violence at home and work. Things are better and we should pay tribute to the trailblazing women who went before. I know that those trailblazing women, like the suffragettes, like the pilloried women of the s and the women who opened the first women’s refuges in the s would not want me to swoon with gratitude for how far we’ve come, they would want me to keep on demanding more.   Domestic and sexual violence are now far less socially acceptable than they used to be. But polling has shown that many in the general public think the #metoo movement has gone too far, somewhat suggesting we still think women should have to put up with a certain level of sexual harassment at work without complaint. Rape convictions remain low between -% and still two women are murdered every week at the hands of a partner or family member in the UK. Attitudes have not shted far enough or fast enough to actually keep women safe.  Where I work huge progress has been made, with women representing now a third of all Members of Parliament, unthinkable  years ago. I ’ll get out the party poppers and shake the champagne when it is % and not before! Yes the world has changed. Yes we should cheer, but when I look around at work, it is still the women having to be just that bit more brilliant to get ahead, it is the women who receive the most abuse, violence and hatred and it is still the women who get asked, ‘How do you cope being an MP and having kids ’ I will have it all when they ask Jacob Rees-Mogg that question not me. story: NewsMeghan Markle and Harrys baby wont be prince or princess - but will have titleThe boy or girl, expected in the Spring of , will not have a royal title due to limits imposed by Prince Harrys great great grandfatherShareCommentsByLaura ElstonCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are about to embark on their first Royal Tour - and Meghan is pregnant"Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex have kept many details of their pregnancy tightly under wraps. He or she will not be a prince nor a princess unless the Queen steps in. Thats because King George V - Harrys great great grandfather - limited titles within the royal family in . This means Harry and Meghans first born, as a great-grandchild of the Queen, is too far down the line of succession to be an HRH. The baby will be seventh in the line, pushing Princess Eugenie to th place.   George V declared that: The grandchildren of the sons of any such Sovereign in the direct male lineshall have and enjoy in all occasions the style and title enjoyed by the children of Dukes of these Our Realms. The eldest son and heir apparent of a duke can use one of his fathers lesser grade peerage titles by courtesy, according to Debretts. So a first son of Harrys would become Earl of Dumbarton - one of the subsidiary titles Harry received from the Queen on the morning of his wedding. A daughter would be LadyMountbatten-Windsor, and any subsequent sons LordMounbatten-Windsor.  Sometimes the Queen does make changes to allow children to be HRHs and princes and princesses. Ahead of Prince Georges birth, the monarch issued a Letters Patent to ensure the Cambridge children had fitting titles. Without this Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis would have been a Lady and a Lord instead, but Prince George, as the eldest son of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales, would still have been a prince. The Queen could decide to do the same for Harry and Meghans baby, but has not yet done so.  The duke may choose to heed the words of his cousin Zara Tindall when discussing such matters with the Queen, and deciding which titles his child should use. Zara, who was born Miss Zara Phillips, has spoken of how not having a title was a blessing. Ive been very lucky. story: NewsWoolly mammoth tooth from , years ago found in rock where it shouldnt beThe remarkable find came in Charmouth Beach along the so-called Jurassic Coast in DorsetShareCommentsByJim Hardy:,  MAR NewsSebastian found a fossilised tooth bigger than his fist at the clf-face rocks along so-called Jurassic Coast in Dorset "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA schoolboy was shocked when he found a mammoth tooth dating back , years. The eight-year-old, named only as Sebastian, was with other fossil hunters scouring the clf-face rocks along so-called Jurassic Coast in Dorset. The boy was taking part in one of Charmouth Heritage Coast Centres fossil walks on Charmouth Beach when young Seb found the tooth, from a ft tall woolly mammoth. Bigger than elephants, they plodded about during the Ice Age but gradually died out and became extinct. Alison Ferris, the centres deputy senior warden, said: It is an unusual find because our layers here are Jurassic, approximately  million years old, and mammoths are obviously not Jurassic. The tooth would have washed out from possibly the river from now-eroded layers from the last Ice Ages. As part of the West Dorset Fossil Collecting Code, it is an important find because it is rare for this area.   We usually find Jurassic fossils here from a marine environment, whereas this fossil represents a whole dferent terrestrial environment in a dferent age. It helps to piece together a little more of what Dorset could have been like thousands of years ago and what kind of animals were living here. We cant be sure where the tooth came from -it has travelled down the river, how far  But other Ice Age fossils have been found locally, such as the Honiton Hippo, so we know these animals would have been roaming in Dorset and Devon. It is great that anyone can help find these fossils and Sebastian did so in a safe place, following the collecting code of conduct. You dont have to be a professional collector to make these amazing discoveries.  Sebastian decided to retain his find and a photo of the tooth was sent to the centres Ice Age fossil expert, who said that although it was dficult to tell the exact age, it was likely around , years old. Professor Danielle Schreve, Royal Holloway University of London and patron of Charmouth Heritage Coast Centre, said It is part of a mammoth molar - I think eight enamel plates although it is hard to tell from the photo. It is very battered and worn so I am afraid I cant say more as to whether it is an upper or lower tooth, or indeed which tooth it is. However, it is definitely a woolly mammoth, Mammuthus primigenius, and therefore, although it could be as old as , years, the first appearance of this species in Britain, it is much more likely to date to the period between , and , years ago, the Middle Devensian, when these animals were very common in Britain, and , years old would therefore be a reasonable estimate.

The animals are being thrown down wells, tied to railings or abandoned as their owners dont want to pay for their upkeep until the start of the next season. These working dogs, known as galgos, are abandoned to terrible fates at the end of each season, say animal welfare campaigners. Campaigners say Spain has , registered galgos and around a quarter of them are abandoned at the end of each season. Owners throw the dogs down wells and block the entrances so they cant escape.  Anna Clements leads a campaign to save these greyhounds and told Mail Online: This is Spains dirty secret and something tourists rarely see.We are expecting an influx of thousands of abandoned dogs but we, and other charities, cannot cope. We cannot save them all. They are brutally treated when the hunters have finished with them - some are thrown down wells and the well opening is blocked off with wood. But some survive and we had one recently who was saved when a passerby heard her cries. She was lying in water at the bottom of the well, was badly malnourished and had deep gashes on her neck. The fire brigade was able to winch her to safety and she is now recovering with a family where she is a loved pet. These working dogs are a distant relative of British greyhounds and are used for hunting and coursing.   This is where two dogs compete to to run down a hare over open land. Galgos that dont compete well are then discarded by their shamed owners. Because theyre regarded as working dogs, they dont come under Spains legislation on the protection of pets.  Footage shows a dog being rescued from a well in Toleda,  miles south west from Madrid, but happily the galgo is now living with a family in Barcelona. Anna says people should be more outraged by the practise but she says its a long-held tradition in some rural areas and some people are too scared to speak out. This cruelty is not what tourists see but the government is slow to take action because the hunting lobby is so powerful, she said.

story: NewsSchoolboys save child, , with makesht net after he plunges from ski ltQuick-thinking Joshua Ravensbergen, , and his friends were on the slopes at Grouse Mountain near Vancouver, Canada, when the boy slipped from his seatShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video heart-stopping-moment-dangling-boy-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFive schoolboys caught a terried eight-year-old in a makesht safety net after he dropped from a ski lt. Quick-thinking Joshua Ravensbergen, , and his friends were on the slopes below when the boy slipped from his seat and his dad caught him by the wrist. He said the lt kept going higher and higher until it was too late for the boy to jump to safety. Joshua said they feared he would be hurtthey did not do something to help as adults stood by, so they grabbed the orange fencing and some padding from a pillar and rushed beneath the chairlt. When the boy could no longer hold on, he let himself fall and was safely caught by the boys, who were about ft below.   Joshua said: “People were there but were just standing looking at the kid, not knowing what to do.” The drama was caught on video at Grouse Mountain near Vancouver, Canada. Joshua’s friend Gabriel Nielson said it took some time to convince the boy to kick off his skis and let go of his father.   “At one point, we were just like, ‘OK, you just need to trust us, you just need to drop,” said Gabriel. The child was on the chairlt was with his parents and his three-year-old sister, who the father was also trying to hang on to while struggling to cling to his son. A Grouse Mountain Resorts spokeswoman said the boy was uninjured but went to hospital as a precautionary measure.

title: brentford arab to cycle from dundee uniteds tannadice ground to london
story: A football friendship that kicked off with a chance meeting in a Berlin bar while watching Andy Murray win Wimbledon will see a Brentford fan literally get on his bike at Tannadice on Monday and cycle almost  miles back “home” to the London club’s Grfin Park.In the process, Steve Tidy will take in four games and, most important of all, raise around £, for the Alzheimer’s Trust.The -year-old has travelled north to meet up with good mate Pat McCarron, who’s well-known among Arabs as chairman of the group Fans United, and will take in the Scottish Cup clash with Inverness Caley before setting off the following morning.And his arduous route south is all down to that friendship.“It was back in  and Brentford were in Berlin for pre-season. Myself and a mate were looking for somewhere to watch the tennis and, by chance, we met up with Pat and a few other United fans,” he said. “We had a good bit of banter and we’ve kept in touch since.”The friendship with Pat and other United fans actually led to the formation of a unique supporters’ club, the BeeArabs, so when Steve was planning his latest charity bike ride, this seemed an obvious route to take.“We thought it would be a good idea to start at Tannadice and head for Grfin Park. I had actually planned it as a practice run before I cycle from London to Paris and back via Guernsey in the summer, but this might be an even bigger task.“That said, my biggest challenge could be surviving the weekend with Pat before I set off on the bike!”Once he’s on his way, Steve will complete the journey in stages and take in Brentford games at Middlesbrough and Sheffield United before arriving at Grfin Park just in time for the clash with West Brom later this month.And thanks to the support he’s already receiving, he hopes to pass a personal milestone with his fund- raising efforts.“I got into cycling a few years back and I’ve done a charity ride to Amsterdam to raise money. It’s a great way to stay fit and, by the time I’ve completed this journey, I should have raised around £, in all for a few charities, so that’s not bad.“I am loving the support I am getting from all in Dundee. It’s overwhelming how many nice people there are from Dundee to Durham, Hartlepool to Leeds, Sheffield to London.”

title: comeback kid paul mcmullan set for new dundee united deal
story: Paul McMullan’s rebirth as a Dundee United player is set to be confirmed with a new contract for next season.As recently as last August, the former Celtic kid was told he was free to find a new club.At that time Partick Thistle were showing a strong interest but he decided to stay on and fight for his place at Tannadice.And since Robbie Neilson took over as manager in October, the -year-old has made  appearances and is again seen as a part of the squad.McMullan was signed up by Ray McKinnon in the summer of  and was a regular until falling out of favour under Csaba Laszlo early this season.Under the current boss, however, he’s played his part in United hauling themselves back into the Championship promotion race.

title: dundee duo set up bakery specialising in birthday cakes for dogs
story: Two Dundee friends have opened a bakery specialising in making birthday cakes for dogs.Cheryl Walker, , and Amy Plummer, , have been inundated with orders since opening Dundee Dog Kitchen – sparking what they hope will be a new trend in the pet world.Cheryl, who lives in Fintry, said she had the idea after struggling to find a fresh cake for her own collie Tess’s first birthday.She said: “I wanted to throw Tess a party and give her a big treat.“I wanted to get her a cake but I couldn’t find anything.“I ended up ordering a cake online which came wrapped in cellophane and had a six-month shelf le – there just wasn’t anyone making anything fresh.”Cheryl and Amy joined forces to fill the gap in the market and opened their pet bakery in December.Their cakes are sugar-free and are packed with carrots, yoghurt, honey, peanut butter and other healthy ingredients which are all locally produced and contain health benefits for the dogs.Amy, who lives in Lochee, said: “We get a mixed reaction when we tell people what we’re doing, but dog lovers are very enthusiastic about it.“It’s taken off really quickly which is all a bit bizarre but very exciting.”Pet owner Imogen Hynd, , couldn’t wait to get a special carrot cake made for her black Labrador Skye on her first birthday.Imogen, of Broughty Ferry, said: “We wanted to mark the occasion because we love her to bits – she’s our little fur baby.“She’s part of the family. You’d do that for a human member of the family, so why not do it for a dog too “We wanted to treat her because she deserves it.”And it seems pet owners across the city agree. Dundee Dog Kitchen has had  birthday cake orders over the next two months.It sold  Valentine “pupcakes” and  Christmas cakes at its launch.Cheryl added: “We’re in a new age of pet ownership where people treat their dogs like family, which is why I think our idea has really caught on.”

title: dundee man denies repeatedly striking mans head with a hammer
story: William Scott, of Cleghorn Street, appeared in private accused of carrying out a hammer attack.It is alleged that Scott assaulted Thomas Foote at an address on Baffin Street on Wednesday last week.The -year-old faces a single charge of repeatedly striking Mr Foote on the head with a hammer to his severe injury and permanent disfigurement.No plea or declaration was made on his behalf during the private hearing.Scott’s case was continued for further examination and he was remanded in custody.

title: dundee people ailsa doing her bit to help save orangutans
story: A Dundee youngster is doing her bit to help save orangutans in the wild.Ailsa Templeton has decided to raise funds for the Orangutan Foundation.The P pupil at Longforgan Primary has been fundraising for four months and has so far raised nearly £.Now she is organising her biggest event yet which will involve her having some of her hair chopped off.Ailsa’s dad Alan said: “She was inspired to raise funds for the Orangutan Foundation after she watched a couple of BBC nature programmes.“Blue Planet  highlighted to her the rising impact of human activity on the natural world and Red Ape made her horried about the plight of orangutans.“Ailsa is quite nervous about getting her hair cut so short, given that she’s kept it long for years and isn’t sure whether she’ll really like the style.“Nevertheless, she knows that she is making a dference with the money she is raising.”The haircut takes place at Longforgan Church Hall on March . Ailsa has also been making jewellery from sea glasswhich she will be selling alongside cakes on the day.Alan added: “ My we Lindsey and I are immensely proud of what Ailsa has achieved so far.“She has a great deal of drive and spirit and we are really pleased that she is so determined.”

title: dundee residents urged to apply for money to bring community projects to life
story: Douglas youngsters are being encouraged to apply for funding to see their own community projects come to le.A youth bank scheme has been set up by the East End community organisation RockSolid.Co-ordinator Mary Richmond said the youth bank group is made up of young people who fundraise through a number of community based activities.She said: “They raise money by selling arts and crafts at local stalls to fund things which benefit the community.“It’s completely up to them how they raise the money.“We have about £, in the pot at the moment which gives them the opportunity to do whatever benefits the community.”She added: “The projects could be anything from buying a laptop for young people to do homework at after school clubs, to putting dog bags in local parks.“We have also done training around money management with the group.“We want to get more applications in – people don’t realise it’s free money and costs nothing to put your application in.“Obviously you have to say how your project will improve the community and prove where the money is going.”Mary added applications to get money from the youth bank are open all year round for people living in Douglas.Grants of up to £ can be applied for to put the projects in action, as long as there are two young people aged between - involved in the process.Applications are paper-based and can be picked up at Douglas and Mid Craigie Church on Balbeggie Place.It comes as the group is giving budding young photographers the chance to develop their skills.New group sessions will run throughout the next school term and a professional photographer has been enlisted to help.The team meets every Monday from -pm at the church.

title: school site left a dumping ground
story: Residents living near the former Menzieshill High School have claimed the area has become a “dumping ground” since its closure.Locals on Tweed Crescent have said the area has gone “rapidly downhill” since the school shut its doors in . vw, px"  Thomas Curran, , has lived in Menzieshill for more than  years and claims communal footpaths near the school are now laden with rubbish.He said it took weeks to try to get trees and branches cleared away following high winds at the turn of the year.Mr Curran added the old school playing fields had overgrown.He said: “The problem with the footpaths near Tweed Crescent has been going on for years.“Since the school was closed we’ve been given the impression this area of Menzieshill has been forgotten about.“There are beer cans, carrier bags and dog waste bags lying on the path.“I’ve made attempts to speak with ward councillors and Dundee City Council about the issues.”The pensioner revealed he had to take matters into his own hands by repairing some of the fencing that had been damaged by the trees.He added: “The place is definitely going downhill. The fiasco with getting the trees removed that were damaged during the high winds recently was a nightmare.“We get the impression everyone is passing the buck and not dealing with the problem.“I’ve tried to speak with everyone and anyone about who is responsible for maintaining the grounds at the school site.“The grass on the playing fields is over a foot high.”A spokesman for Dundee City Council confirmed the local authority still owned the land.He added: “We are aware of the situation and will put measures in place to have the area tidied up.”

title: BrewDog eyes up Inverness site for bar
story: A CITY bakery looks set to make way for a hip new bar in Inverness city centre.The Ashes bakery chain has confirmed this week that it is ldquoat an advanced stage of negotiations over vacating its premises in Church Street to make way for Aberdeenshire-based BrewDog.It was revealed last month that the pub chain, which has grown rapidly in the past few years and now employs more than  staff in dozens of bars across the UK, was keen to come to the Highland capital.While there has been no official confirmation from BrewDog itself Ali Asher, joint managing director of the Ashers chain, confirmed talks are progressing.ldquoitrsquos clearly a very good site for that type of operation now, he said, adding that Ashers itself will not be leaving the city centre but simply moving.ldquoWe have also identied a location round the corner on Union Street which we plan to relocate to at the same time, he said.ldquoWe hope the necessary consents and assistance from the authorities and our local tradesmen will facilitate this being a smooth transition.Mr Asher also revealed plans for a refurbishment of his chainrsquos cafe at the Farraline Park bus station.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming many loyal and new customers to both these shops and wish BrewDog all the best, he added.BrewDog was launched in Fraserburgh in  by friends Martin Dickie and James Watt, both then , with a mission to increase interest in craft beer.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Demolition team pull down old college site
story: The work is being carried out by Bonnybridge-based Central Demolition and is set to finish in July.Cha Tulloch, from Central Demolition, said the project was on track after the initial internal sweep.ldquoThe first stage was soft stripping when we emptied internal furnishings which were left behind, like desks and chairs, and donated them to local charities and businesses, she said.The building, which dates back to the s, has been vacant since the new campus opened in . The .-acre site sits next to the cityrsquos new purpose-built justice centre, which is going up rapidly.Highland Council has earmarked the college site for mixed-use development.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Loch Ness Monster the subject of new master pie ce
story: To celebrate British Pie Week, pastry specialists Jus-Rol decided to create an art pie-ce of Nessie out of pies.The image is made up of more than  handmade pies, using a combination of shortcrust, puff and filo pastry.The masterpiece took three days to create and cocoa powder, currants, sesame seeds, caster sugar and brown sugar were used for the outlining and some of the detailing.Holly Bouldin from Jus-Rol says, ldquoJus-Rol, British Pie Week aims to inspire the nation to celebrate one of the greatest British classic foods and we wanted to pay tribute to that love by creating an impressive image which is synonymous with Scotland.As well as the artwork, Jus-Rol ran a UK-wide poll ahead of pie week, which runs next week. It uncovered that the average Scot eats three pies a month and Scotlandrsquos all-time favourite flavour was beef and ale.The poll also showed that one in  Scots bake a homemade pie twice a month. Andthere isnrsquot a rolling pin to hand Scottish people are the most likely, in the UK, to reach for a wine bottle as an alternative.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Shock at extent of tree felling by the Caledonian Canal in Inverness
story: Councillor Duncan Macpherson believes too many trees have been chopped down to make way for the latest phase of the Inverness West Link.Oak trees have been brought down along the canal side to make way for a second swing bridge and poplar trees along the edge of the A at Glenurquhart Road have also been felled in the name of health and safety.Cllr Macpherson said he and many others were shocked to see the extent of the felling.He said: ldquoI can understand the need to have one or two trees down for the new swing bridge but it seems to me like theyrsquove just gone and taken every single tree down. Did they really need to do that ldquoI wouldnrsquot exactly call myself a tree-hugger but Irsquom thinking lsquoguys come on, are you sure you needed to take that many down rsquoInverness musician Roderick Mackenzie, who lives nearby and is concerned about protecting the environment, said it made him feel ill to see mature trees being cut down.ldquoThis is abuse of the environment, he said. ldquoItrsquos sickening.A council spokesman said it was ldquoalways troubling to see mature trees removed but insisted the scale of the operation was necessary.And he said an environmental survey had been carried out before the felling started to rule out the presence of bird nests, bat roosts and similar habitats in the trees.He added: ldquoThe poplar trees adjacent to the A were in very poor condition and would have needed signicant reductions or complete removal, regardless of the development.ldquoPart of the stage two works will develop park land and there is a comprehensive replanting plan incorporated into the works commencing later this year.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Ski slope plan for ex quarry outside Inverness
story: Inverness Snowsports Centrehas been told by Highland Council that it does not require an environmental impact assessmentat this stage for the proposed development at Torvean on the A Loch Ness road.ISC was formed by a group of snowsports and mountain bike enthusiasts who believe Inverness should have a venue for such activities for all ages and abilities.Project manager Helen Morgan said they envisage all-year-round attractions including mountain biking, zip wires, high rope trails and downhill tubing, all based around a snowsports core. It is estimated a pound million to pound million investment is required.The plan includes a building for catering, changing and hire of equipment, plusrooms available for rent.Panoramic viewing areas will be provided from where the sporting activities can be observed in comfort.The council has been told there will be ldquonegligible noise or light pollution as most of the development would be below the top rim of the quarry. There will be some removal of scrub trees and gorse and brambles, but mature trees will not be felled.The area is a Site of Special Scientic Interest as it is formed by an esker, an unusual geological feature where a long ridge of gravel and other sediment has been deposited by meltwater from a retreating glacier or ice sheet. It is one of the reasons gravel extraction was halted back in the s.The area is now used by dog walkers, ramblers, motorbike scramblers and X off-road fans.Inverness Snowsports Centre has launched an online Just Giving plea to raise pound, to pay for the studies required to support a formal planning application.Keen skier Miss Morgansaid they wanted to ensure people of all abilities had access to the activities.Cllr Bill Boyd, Inverness West, said: ldquoThis plan sounds quite exciting, but I hope they can come up with funding because the council is not in a position to fund it at the moment.ldquoIt could be an ideal centre for local people, schools and visitors.Monday  Mar  : AM

title: dons and gers draw in frenetic scottish cup tie
story: A replay will be required to settle the Scottish Cup quarter-final between Aberdeen and Rangers after an action-packed - draw at Pittodrie.Sam Cosgrove fired the Dons ahead from the penalty spot early on, but Joe Worrall#s leveller just after half-time means a replay will take place on Tuesday March  at Ibrox.Dons boss Derek McInnes made one change from the team that lost - to Hamilton on Wednesday. Gary Mackay-Steven recovered from a knock to start with Niall McGinn dropping to the bench.Left-back Max Lowe gave the hosts a further boost by shaking off a knee problem, which had forced him off against Accies, to start.After a cagey opening Aberdeen hit the front from the penalty spot on  minutes.The spot-kick was awarded in the ninth minute when Lowe robbed James Tavernier on the left, Lowe drove forward and slipped the ball through for Mackay-Steven who was scythed down by Connor Goldson on the slide.Referee Kevin Clancy had no hesitation in pointing to the spot and after a two minute delay while Mackay-Steven got treatment Cosgrove stepped up and fired the ball into the bottom right corner with his right foot despite Allan McGregor getting a touch on the effort.The Gers tried to respond and shortly after Alfredo Morelos got the run on Andy Considine, but his low shot from the right side of the box was saved by Joe Lewis at the front post.On the quarter hour the Colombian striker was booked for a blatant e in the area with Considine at his back and seconds later Mackay-Steven had to be withdrawn, the winger still suffering after Goldson#s challenge which resulted in the penalty, McGinn came on.It was fine display from the Reds in the opening half an hour as they got on top of Rangers and didn#t give them a chance to play.In the nd minute it was nearly two when Greg Stewart#s free-kick from the left found Scott McKenna at the back post and his header was tipped over by McGregor.However the Dons were given a warning for minutes later. Tavernier appeared to trip Cosgrove on the edge of the box, but Clancy didn#t give it and Rangers broke upfield.Ryan Kent was sent clear down the left but Dom Ball chased back and did enough to cause him to lash high and wide.In first half stoppage time Ball made a timely intervention when Scott Arfield took advantage of Lewis Ferguson to find Tavenier, his low ball into the area looked like it would find Morelos but Ball came across to clear.After an excellent first half the Dons started the second period poorly and Rangers were level within three minutes.Stewart gave away a needless corner on the left after overplay and from Kent#s inswinging delivery Worrall was completely free at the back post to volley home from six yards.Aberdeen were rattled and on  minutes Lowe made a crucial challenge to deny Kent after he burst through two tackles.There was another warning just before the hour when the Govan side broke from an Aberdeen corner. Daniel Candeias sprinted down the right and intelligently played the ball for Kent on the left side of the area, the winger teed up Arfield who lted a shot over the bar.On  minutes there was a scramble in the Gers box from a McGinn corner McKenna had a header blocked and a Cosgrove shot was also thwarted before the ball was smuggled away.The game was becoming more fraught as it entered the last  minutes with players on both sides flinging themselves into tackles.On  minutes the Dons were wondering how they weren#t in front. McGinn swirled in a free-kick from the right, McKenna won the header, Ball hooked it across goal and then Considine#s low strike was saved by the foot of McGregor.Both teams were trying to win the tie in a frenetic finale, with two minutes of the  left Considine made a magnicent block to stop Morelos converting from Kent#s corner on the left.Aberdeen: Joe Lewis, Dominic Ball, Scott McKenna, Andy Considine, Max Lowe, Lewis Ferguson, Graeme Shinnie, Connor McLennan , Greg Stewart, Gary Mackay-Steven , Sam Cosgrove.Subs not used: Tomas Cerny, Stephen Gleeson, Stevie May, Michael Devlin, Dean Campbell.Rangers: Allan McGregor, James Tavernier, Joe Worrall, Connor Goldson, Borna Barisic, Ryan Jack, Glen Kamara, Scott Arfield, Daniel Candeias, Alfredo Morelos, Ryan Kent.Subs not used: Wes Foderingham, Jermain Defoe, Kyle Lafferty, Andy Halliday, Ross McCrorie, Nikola Katic, Lassana Coulibaly.

title: scott mckenna too sharp for needle match says joe lewis
story: Joe Lewis insists team-mate Scott McKenna won’t repeat the mistake he made the last time Aberdeen played Rangers.Centre-back McKenna was sent off for retaliation during the - Premiership defeat at Pittodrie last month.The Scotland international kicked out at Rangers striker Alfredo Morelos after the Colombian – who was also sent off – had stamped on him.McKenna is set to start today#s Scottish Cup quarter-final tie between the Reds and Gers at Pittodrie and Lewis says the defender won’t be affected by his dismissal.The goalkeeper said: “Discipline can be important and it’s unlike Scott to act like he did in the last game.“He put his hand up after the game and said he’d made a mistake.“We move on because he is not a player who will do that again and I’m convinced of that.“If Scott is back in the team he will be looking to make amends by making sure the defensive performance is very good.“He’s a great guy, Scott. Psychologically, he is brilliant and he is laid-back.“That one incident is very unlike him and I’m sure it won’t happen again.“In terms of him maturing as a player, that will be a great lesson for him going forward.”The Dons seem to bring the worst out in Gers striker Morelos who has been sent off on each of the three occasions he’s faced Aberdeen this season.Despite his hot-headedness he is still a threat and has netted  goals in all competitions this term.Two of those came at Pittodrie in the - win last month prior to his red card.Lewis knows it’s important for the Dons to nully his threat today.He added: “He is an excellent player and they have a lot of very good players in their team after spending a lot of money.“You expect a strong squad from them and they have strength in depth and quality whoever plays for them.“Morelos has got quality, but we have to watch out for all of them.“We have gted away a few clean sheets this season and we would have liked to have had a few more.“As a defensive unit it would be goodwe could keep another clean sheet on Sunday.”

title: aberdeen charity charlie house launches new partnership with teca
story: An Aberdeen children#s charity has announced a two-year partnership with a major new concert venue.Charlie House, which supports children and young people with complex disabilities and le- limiting conditions, has secured a deal with state-of-the-art The Event Complex Aberdeen .A vital link for the city charity, it will also see the exhibition centre create a dedicated changing place for families with children with complex disabilities.TECA, which will replace the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre , is on track to open in summer this year at its new location in Bucksburn.Susan Crighton, director of fundraising at Charlie House, said: “We are thrilled to announce this key partnership for   and very much look forward to working with the team. Our corporate partnerships are vital to enable us to continue to deliver and expand our services to support families both in Aberdeen City and Shire and the wider north-east of Scotland.”Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local charlie-house-launches--million-appeal-to-build-specialist-care-centre-for-north-east-children embed # secretMttFeRTBR" data-secret"MttFeRTBR" width"" "" title"#Charlie House launches £ million appeal to build specialist care centre for north-east children# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Louise Stewart, the arena’s head of entertainment, sales and marketing, said: “The new venue is set to make concert attendance much more accessible for the families who are supported by Charlie House with a specic changing place being installed, which is essential to enable the families to spend extended time away from home.“We are also thrilled to continue to be part of Attitude is Everything, which improves deaf and disabled people’s access to live music by working in partnership with audiences, artists and the music industry to implement a charter of best practice across the UK, while we work towards achieving our gold standard.”The charity is currently raising £ million to build the first specialist support centre in the north-east.

title: aberdeen city centre road to close for works
story: Two city centre roads are to be affected by work being carried out later this month.The Union Terrace slip road between Denburn Viaduct and Union Terrace will shut on March  from am until pm.The busy junction is to close in order to facilitate works carried out by BT on Denburn Viaduct, with vehicles able to turn left at the traffic lights instead.On the same day, vehicles will not be able to stop for any purpose on either side of College Street between Marywell Street and Guild Street, and on the east side of the southbound carriageway of Denburn Road, near its junction with Patagonian Court.The traffic restrictions will be in force from am until midnight.Vehicles associated with the temporary bus link for Network Rail will be exempt, as the restrictions are in place while repair works are carried out by the firm on the Aberdeen to Dundee line.

title: north east stargazer snaps spacex dragon streaking across sky
story: A north-east stargazer had an early start to snap a space capsule.Steven Shanks, , rose from bed at am to grab a picture of the SpaceX Dragon making its way to the International Space Station.The capsule launched from Florida on Saturday and could be seen streaking across the sky above the north-east yesterday morning.Steven, a manager in the oil and gas sector, did not want to miss the chance to get a spectacular picture.He said: “I’m quite a follower of these types of space activities.“I’d been following the launch for a few weeks and I used an app to checkwe’d be able to see the space station, which there was early on Sunday morning.“I noticed that the Dragon would be docking soon after that and wonderedI’d be able to see them together.“So I was able to set up the camera, get a couple of shots, and get back to my bed.”The flight is part of Nasa testing which could eventually see passengers carried into space in the capsule.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Ropework played host to this keenly contested local derby which was watched by a healthy crowd on Saturday February .And for the second time this season, Red Star and Campbeltown Pupils shared the points in a match both sides will feel they could have won.Both sides were struggling for fluency in the opening stages but Red Star settled first and grabbed the opening goal after  minutes. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. story: NewsFamilys new hope as £, is raised to send son to America for cerebral palsy treatmentThe six-year-old will be heading to America after the huge sum of money was raised to fund his treatment.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  MAR NewsSaul with brothers Clay and Mylo and mum and dad, Karen and Stuart "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family’s bid to help their son walk again is set for take-off. Little Saul Wylie will travel to America for le-changing treatment on his severe form of cerebral palsy. The six-year-old, who weighed just lb at birth, has made the waiting list for pioneering surgery. There has been a massive charity effort across Ayrshire to fund the trip, with pound, raised in little over six months.Mum Karen, , told the Ayrshire Post : “To achieve this so quickly is beyond our wildest dreams.“We set a target of two years to get the money but the community reaction has been incredible.” Saul, of Tarbolton, has to go to the States because his aggressive condition is not treated on the NHS. The brave kid lives with spastic diplegia cerebral palsy, which affects his muscle tone and leaves him unable to walk unaided. Karen said: “Saul’s dream is to be able to stand by himself and take independent steps and maybe even one day walk around school with his friends. “Like every parent, we long for endless opportunities for our boy. “Saul is very happy and determined but we just want him to have the best opportunity at a better quality of le and to become as independent as possible.”  Medication, Botox, and even trampoline therapy have all been used to try and limit Saul’s pain. But his spot at St Louis Children’s Hospital in Missouri could be the ultimate answer. Karen said: “The operation is called selective dorsal rhizotomy, which will reduce Saul’s muscle stfness. “Added to intensive rehab, it will allow Saul to stand independently and potentially walk again. Unfortunately there is a waiting list for international patients so Saul’s surgery is not scheduled until . “But because we are in a position to go we have been put on their cancellation list and are keeping our fingers crossed.” Karen and husband Stuart have thrown themselves into a string of fundraising events with the ‘Steps For Saul’ campaign gathering momentum. Karen said: “We’ve done everything from coffee mornings to quiz nights and we can’t thank people enough for their response. “There have been skyes, race nights, sponsored cycles and I also did the Great Scottish Run. “People have taken Saul to their hearts and we’ve even had donations from as far afield as America, New Zealand, Canada and Ireland. “Hopefully he now has the chance he deserves.” • An open ice skate for Saul will take place at Ayr Ice Rink on Sunday, April , from -pm.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnDrugsCerebral palsyCharityAyr NewsAyr

title: tributes paid mr gaiety ayr
story: NewsTributes paid to Mr Gaiety as Ayr theatre legend Bernard Cotton diesBernard Cotton was a do-it-all theatre manager in the Gaietys pomp and booked acts like Billy Connolly, Ken Dodd and Barbara Windsor.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsBernard outside his beloved Gaiety "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe man who was ‘Mr Gaiety’ in Ayr for nearly two decades has died suddenly, aged , writes Edwin Lawrence. Bernard Cotton was at Alloway Bowling Club when he collapsed and died on Thursday last week. He had been club champion on ious occasions, the last time in . But it was as manager of the Gaiety from  to  that Bernard made his biggest impact. He took over at a critical time when the theatre’s ownership passed from the Popplewell family to the Royal Burgh of Ayr. But Bernard was the perfect man for the job, having managed the Empire Theatre in his home town of Sunderland. There he had hosted shows featuring The Beatles and Hollywood legend Marlene Dietrich. “He even shared a McEwan’s Export with Marlene,” said son Sam, . “They didn’t have any champagne to give Marlene so she had what dad was drinking - only with ice.”. Bernard was no ordinary theatre manager and often directed big showpiece events like pantos and summer season shows. He quickly became respected by some of the biggest names on the Scottish scene. He booked acts like Jimmy Logan, Billy Connolly, Rikki Fulton, Jack Milroy and perennial Gaiety favourite Johnnie Beattie. Bernard also knew some of the biggest UK stars, bringing Ken Dodd, Barbara Windsor, Pat Phoenix and Lionel Blair to the Gaiety.  He did not shy away from tough decisions, booking the controversial erotic revue ‘Oh! Calcutta!’ in . He later recalled: “It brought much adverse publicity and even the poster was frowned upon - to such an extent that the management agreed to cover over the female posterior that was displayed upon it.” However, the show was a massive financial success with only two unsold seats in a week-long run. Sam remembers his dad sharing a story of a couple walking out of the show in high dudgeon. Bernard asked them why, as it had been advertised as an X-rated show. The shocked couple told him they thought they had booked to see ‘Oklahoma!’. Another of Bernard’s controversial - but highly successful - bookings was ‘The Rocky Horror Show’, which attracts enthusiastic fans who often dress in stockings, corsets and suspenders. For although Bernard principally ran a family theatre, he believed it should cater for all tastes. A post on the Gaiety Facebook page says: “We are deeply saddened to hear about the loss of Bernard Cotton, a much loved colleague, dedicated family man and friend to all. “Bernard was and is a Gaiety institution, from his own time managing our Old Lady to helping us shape her future. We simply couldn’t have done it without his support. “His guidance, golden nuggets from years gone by, witty humour and love for delivering high-quality theatre for all were second to none. He will be sorely missed by us all. “At this sad time we are thinking of his beloved we Vida and children Julia and Sam. “We wish them moments of peace and comfort as they remember a husband, father and friend who was so cherished. “He will forever be in our hearts and minds and will always have a place in his beloved theatre.”  Musician Martin Henderson commented: “Bernard was witty, professional and a family man, a privilege to have worked for many years in the Gaiety while Bernard and Vida were at the helm. “He ran a tight ship but embraced risky ventures like our annual mock panto, which needs no explanation to Gaiety staff. A sad loss to Scottish theatre and his family.” Journalist Alistair Nicol said: “I met Bernard when I was deputy editor of the Ayrshire Post in  and he was always helpful and a great inspiration to all around him in the entertainment world.” Bernard Cotton was a former president of the Rotary Club of Ayr He is survived by we Vida, a stalwart Gaiety volunteer who formerly ran the theatre’s costume department London-based daughter Julia, , a former dancer and Brighton-based son Sam. His funeral service is at noon on Wednesday, March , at Masonhill Crematorium.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnBilly ConnollyFacebookThe BeatlesAyrSocial mediaAyr News

title: dealer-admits-selling-ecstasy-to-12-year-olds-in-galashiels
story: A DRUG dealer from Hawick who sold ecstasy tablets to two -year-olds has been told he could have been facing a murder charge.The schoolboys fell ill after taking taking the pills which contained compounds of the class A drug and required urgent medical treatment.Despite being born with no arms, Jake Moffett overcame his disability by supplying the ecstasy tablets to the two youngsters and pleaded guilty to a drug dealing charge at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Sherf Peter Paterson told the -year-old: "If you dont know this by now, I will tell you this is an extremely serious mater."Supplying class A drugs is a serious matter but to children aged  makes it a lot more serious."It could easily have killed them and you could be facing a charge of murder."Calling for background reports to be prepared before sentencing, the sherf warned Moffett that he would be remanded in custodyhe did not co-operate in the preparation of the reports and failed to turn up for appointments.Tessa Bradley, prosecuting, explained that the police report indicated that Moffett was "very popular among local youngsters" with a major feature being large groups congregating for the consumption of alcohol.She said that Moffett met a -year-old boy in Victoria Park, Galashiels, at around .pm on Thursday, October , and sold him the tablet.The fiscal described how the boys mother went to bed that night leaving her son playing video games.She said: "She got out of bed later on to get some medicine and found her son with large pupils and visibly shaking."The schoolboy received medical treatment and later confirmed that he had purchased the ecstasy tablet from Moffett.A search warrant was obtained for Moffetts home in Crumhaugh Road, Hawick, where pound in cash was recovered along with pink tablets and a mobile phone.Ms Bradley also described an incident on October  when another -year-old had taken what he believed to be an ecstasy tablet and after being found by his mother had to receive treatment at Borders General Hospital.The boy confirmed he had bought the tablet from Moffett.Moffett pleaded guilty to being concerned in the supply of compounds of ecstasy at his Hawick home between August  and October .Sentence was deferred until March  for the production of a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment.
