title: starbucks-eyeing-up-site-in-haddington
story: Euro Garages Ltd, which is transforming the former Raceland karting site near Gladsmuir into a roadside services hub, has applied to East Lothian Council to develop land at Gateside West.The site, off the B West Road, is next to Persimmon Homesrsquo Haddington Manse development.It was previously earmarked for a pub restaurant but could now become home to East Lothianrsquos first Starbucks.The coffee shop giant is not named on the planning application itself but drawings of the proposed development submitted to the local authority by Euro Garages Ltd are labelled as the lsquoStarbucks sitersquo.Says the planning application: ldquoIt is considered that the development will provide both a modern food and drink facility, which will offer an accessible lsquothird placersquo to the surrounding residential areas, for social gatherings and as a meeting place for local community groups.If approved, the coffee shop would employ about  people and be open seven days a week from am to pm, with parking for  vehicles, including two disabled spaces and two electric car spaces.Paul Darling, of the townrsquos community council, had mixed feelings about the project.He said: ldquoIrsquom happy to see some sort of infrastructure but you can already have a cup of coffee every day of the week in Haddington without going into the same establishment twice.Euro Garages was given the green light by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee earlier this month for the former Raceland site.More than  jobs are expected to be created at that site, which will become home to a -hour petrol station and fast food drive-thru, with additional fast food and coffee shop drive-thrus open daily.Euro Garages already has  Starbucks operating out of its sites, which stretch across the UK and beyond.Three of Haddingtonrsquos ward councillors ndash John McMillan, Brian Small and Tom Trotter ndash sit on the local authorityrsquos planning committee, which could make the decision on the plans.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who also represents the town, is not part of the committee and said: ldquoFirstly itrsquos important that whatever plans are put forward that they support our town centre. So, in that respect, I will await to see the ideas that are being put forward by the developer, and will be asking the question as to how they will support this aim.In , planning permission was given for the creation of a pub restaurant on the site, along with  houses and business light industrial units.Although the housing has been completed, neither the industrial units nor pub restaurant have been built.Instead, an unsuccessful bid was made to create  more houses on the site earmarked for the pub restaurant. That was rejected, with the council keen to see the land retained for employment.After being contacted by the Courier for a comment, a spokesperson for Starbucks said: ldquoUnfortunately, we donrsquot have anything to share at the moment.

title: east-lothian-mp-shares-his-views-on-eight-labour-mps-resigning
story: Martin Whitfield, who was elected as MP for East Lothian in , has spoken following eight fellow Labour MPs resigning from the party.Seven MPs ndash Luciana Berger, Ann Coffey, Mike Gapes, Chris Leslie, Gavin Shuker, Angela Smith and Chuka Umunna ndash announced their decision on Monday, which comes in protest at Labour leader Jeremy Corbyns leadership, as well as the handling of allegations of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party.They were joined on Wednesday by an eighth MP, Joan Ryan, as well as three Conservative MPs who resigned from their party.The  MPs will now sit in Parliament as the Independent Group.Commenting on the Labour resignations, Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThe MPs who have resigned are good colleagues and friends and I am very sad that they felt they had no other option but to leave the party.ldquoMy own position is that I was immensely proud to be elected as a Scottish Labour MP here in East Lothian and have never considered leaving."I am Labour through and through and will continue to fight my corner within the party.ldquoHowever, the departure of these seven colleagues highlights the importance of the party leadership urgently addressing issues like anti-Semitism and the behaviour of a minority of members, as well as listening to members and supporters on Brexit.ldquoHistory shows us that it is only when Labour is operating as a broad church, open, inclusive and tolerant of a range of opinions, that it can unite to deliver the change working people need.

title: musselburgh-man-given-interim-asbo
story: Jordan Buchan, , of Goose Green Avenue, has been banned from shouting, swearing, or using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within his property or within Goose Green Avenue, or permitting or encouraging others to do the same.Mr Buchan is also banned from engaging in acts of physical violence or permitting or encouraging others to do the same in or near a property at Goose Green Avenue.The interim ASBO also bans Mr Buchan from generating any kind of excessive noise such as the repeated banging or slamming of doors and having more than two visitors to his property, except those there in the course of their employment.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others."Anyone in East Lothian who is affected by anti-social behaviour can call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on  .

title: couples-quick-wedding-after-brides-dad-given-weeks-to-live
story: Bex Wood, neacutee Cunningham, was not even engaged when she found out that her dad, George Cunningham, had just weeks to live.Bex, along with boyfriend Ali Wood, quickly got engaged and got married just six days after the doctors broke the bad news to her dad.She told the Courier: ldquoThe wedding was brilliant.ldquoIt was quite bittersweet but from looking back at photographs, everybody commented on how happy everybody was.ldquoWe could have made it a sad day but we did not want that.ldquoIt was a still a celebration it was perfect, the weather was great ndash everything.ldquoThat was how it would have gonewe took a couple of years to plan it.George, , of Longniddry, had been suffering from stomach pains last year.Bex told the Courier: ldquoHe was diagnosed with lymphoma last June.ldquoThey said they were putting him on a curative plan and said to him he could be home and cured by Christmas.ldquoHe was getting treatment but then in October he started to get more treatment.ldquoThey did tests and just found out it was not working and he only had weeks to live.Ali and Bex had been together for five years and had spoken of getting married but had never really put any plans into motion.However, after the diagnosis, Ali went shopping for an engagement ring and proposed on the Sunday.The couple, who live in Prestonpans, tied the knot on the Thursday at Longniddry Parish Church before a reception at Archerfield House.Despite the short timeframe, Bex said the couple were not overly stressed by the occasion, with Alirsquos sister-in-law Lyndsay putting things together.Bex, , said: ldquoYou need a team of people to help. We hardly did any of it ourselves ndash Alirsquos sister-in-law pretty much did all of it.ldquoShe was the events planner at Archerfield and she did pretty much all of it.ldquoFamily did bits and pieces but Lyndsay did most of it so we cannot take any of the credit.The happy couple were married on November , with George walking his daughter down the aisle in front of  guests.Medical sales rep Bex said: ldquoHe was absolutely fine on the day.ldquoHe was a bit tired and went for a lie down but he walked me down the aisle no bother.ldquoHe did his speech and the first dance together and then he just sat and everybody chatted to him.George sadly passed away on November , with the funeral taking place in the same church.Bex and Ali, who works as a field sales manager, decided to hold off on a honeymoon, with the couple jetting off to Dubai and the Males next month.Bex added: ldquoWe wanted to spend as much time with him as possible.ldquoWe had no idea in terms of timeframes so we spent everyday with him.An online fundraising page has also been set up to raise money for Bloodwisego to justgiving fundraising alastair-wood

title: substation-plan-at-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-approved
story: The site, which is owned by East Lothian Council and had been earmarked as having the potential to bring more than , jobs to the community, has been at the centre of a battle between the community, the council and windfarm company Inch Cape.Ministers called in the planning application from Inch Cape,which wants to bring energy from a planned offshore windfarm onshore at the site, before East Lothian Council had made any ruling on it.The call-in was controversially made while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was visitingChina, where she met representatives of the Chinese state-owned Red Rock company, which owns Inch Cape.Issuing their decision, Scottish Ministers said they agreed with the Scottish Government reporterrsquos findings that the substation was of ldquonational importance.East Lothian Council and local communities had argued it would ldquosterilise the site for future economic development.However, the reporter noted that the substation would take up less than  per cent of the former power station site.

title: new-cemetery-at-dunbar-gets-the-go-ahead
story: A total of , lairs,  ashes-only lairs and an area of woodland burial space will be created at Newtonlees, on the eastern edge of the town.The announcement brings to an end fears that the town would be left without any burial space.Deer Park Cemetery, opposite the newly-approved burial ground, is nearly at capacity.Now, the new cemetery is expected to serve the people of Dunbar and surrounding area for at least  years.The announcement was welcomed by ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who was keen to see the new cemetery opened quickly.He said: ldquoIt will take time for people to do the work they have to do to get the facility into a place that can be used.ldquoI know Stuart Pryde [council principal amenities officer] and his team have been ready and waiting for this to happen.Deer Park Cemetery, which has , lairs, opened in  and is expected, according to the council, to reach capacity by the summer of next year.Plans to extend the cemetery fell through, with the council then forced to look for land for a new cemetery.Currently, the new site is being used as agricultural land but work is expected to begin in the near future on transforming the .-hectare site off the A.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe supporting information submitted with the application states that the burial site is required to meet both the immediate needs of Dunbar town but also to serve the needs of the wider cluster of communities for the next - years in accordance with the councilrsquos approved Burial Ground Strategy.ldquoThe general layout of the Newtonlees Cemetery reflects best practice in terms of modern burial ground provision.ldquoThe layout affords a degree of choice from traditional coffin interment through interment of cremated remains and an allocation of space for natural burial within a meadow woodland area which will, as it develops, also provide an enhanced setting for the facility.The cemetery is part of larger plans for the site, which were first discussed by councillors in .At that time, plans for more than  houses on land at Newtonlees Farm were approved, despite the area of land being outwith the sites identied at that stage by the councilrsquos Local Development Plan and recommended for refusal by the local authorityrsquos planning officers.At that time, the vote was tied at -, with Mr Hampshire given the casting vote.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said details were still to be finalised before a date could be confirmed for the cemetery opening.She added: ldquoHaving secured approval and agreement to purchase the ground, we can now ensure that local burial space supply will continue for the area without risk of a break in service.

title: tims-tales-the-kings-chair
story: IT HAS been a time of lsquoborrowed daysrsquo recently. Such days are ones which have been borrowed from another month, and I think given the temperature and weather we have had recently the days have been borrowed from May.In , May will have borrowed Februaryrsquos days, so we can expect some unseasonal weather in that month as well, but in a dferent way.Sunday was a borrowed day for sure it was so mild and the later part sunny with a feeling of spring in the air. It was a perfect day for a discovery.We set off to find a place Irsquod only recently heard about. A friend had asked me what I knew about the lsquoKingrsquos Chairrsquo by Gullane. I had to admit that Irsquod never heard of it. He told me one of the holes at the golf course there has this name, but it seems it is named after a location nearby.This set me investigating. Sure enough, I found it marked on the map and searched for an image, which I found on a website called Ancient Stones: a large boulder, shaped like a throne, guarded by two other stones either side. It intrigued me and so our quest began.The starting point of our adventure was Gullane Beach car park. I knew roughly where to look but purposefully hadnrsquot brought the map so that we had a challenge to find the lsquochairrsquo. We knew what it looked like and that we needed to walk along the upper path, not the one that heads for the beach.We went the wrong way at first and got stuck in a mass of sea buckthorn, but on reflection that just added to the sense of adventure and achievement. We soon found our way and then suddenly there it was, up on Gullane Hill. The kids ran excitedly towards the stones, shouting: ldquoFound it, found it.I felt quite exhilarated at the discovery, and to be honest impressed by the sight of the Kingrsquos Chair. I can see how it got its name, as it looks something like a majestic reclining armchair. The two boulders on either side of it look like sentries keeping watch.The kids sat on it, of course, and I had to wait my turn after my we, who reckoned it could just as easily be a lsquoQueenrsquos Chairrsquo.When I finally got a chance to seat my majestic posterior on the chair, I realised the view was majestic as well, with Gullane Beach very visible in the near distance.I reflected on the fact we had recently visited Edinburgh Castle and seen the Stone of Destiny or Stone of Scone, along with the crown jewels. This rather uninspiring stone in Edinburgh Castle may be the coronation stone used for  years in England, but it is not, I am sure, the coronation stone used by ancient kings of Scotland, despite official claims that it is.I think itrsquos pretty clear that Edward I never got his hands on the real Stone of Destiny and I am convinced it has remained in Scotland, hidden somewhere, ever since. It occurred to me that this stone actually better fitted the early description of the original coronation stone at Scone than the one in Edinburgh Castle.ldquoImaginethis is the real Stone of Destiny and has been here all the time, I said fancully out loud. I know it isnrsquot, of course, but I have to saythis Kingrsquos Chair was on display at Edinburgh Castle it would certainly look more authentic.But sadly there seems to be no recorded tradition connected to this Kingrsquos Chair. I could find no story, or reference to the origin of its name. Perhaps some local people have some information on this There is an entry from the s that records the name, citing locals as the source, so there is some historic veracity in its title. But no suggestion is offered for the origin of the name, or any tradition associated with the stone. Its geology I could not say but it doesnrsquot seem to be a glacial erratic.And so we are left to wonder. We discussed how the stone got here and how it got its name. Maybe some children played here many generations ago and gave the boulder its title. Perhaps a Viking king who landed on Gullane Beach sat himself down on this natural throne to survey his warriors at their bloody work.Whatever the origin, the name, the location and the nature of the stone make this a worthwhile and fun discovery, even without a firm legend attached to it.And as I sat on the chair I watched smoke billowing from the coastline a little further to the west, close to the edge of Aberlady nature reserve. What caused the fire I didnrsquot know, but even from a distance it seemed destructive.It was a prophetic sight to witness from the Kingrsquos Chair. It looked like a burning coastline from a Viking raid. Thankfully the distant screech of fire engines told us help was on the way. The children wanted to go see the fire, but we kept our distance from the flames and let the firefighters do their job.So the trip to the Kingrsquos Chair had been an adventure in more ways than one. On our way back, the children advanced dferent theories about the origin of the name. It was universally agreed that a story must be made, but no agreement on the actual tale.ldquoPerhaps, I said, ldquowe should leave it to the imagination of those who search for and discover it, so they can sit and feel the power of the place and get ideas.My imagination was certainly ablaze. I saw the leader of the ancient Gododdin tribe, King Loth, sitting on the stone, looking out to the Firth as he watched his terried daughter in a small coracle being taken out to the open sea, his brutal punishment for her defiance of his authority.The story would fit as her journey began at Aberlady Bay, and so her small craft would have been seen from the Kingrsquos Chair as it passed by, being pulled out to sea by one of the kingrsquos boats.Itrsquos all a fancy of my imagination, of course, but thatrsquos my story. Go find the Kingrsquos Chair for yourself and see what your imagination comes up with!

title: double-cash-boost-for-our-community-kitchen-project-in-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen has been awarded more than pound,, which it will use over the next year.The bulk of the money has come from Big Lottery Scotland, with pound, awarded to see the group expand to three days a week from next month.Already, the project meets on a Tuesday at Haddington Bowling Club.In the coming weeks, it will also meet on a Wednesday and Thursday, hosting dozens of people at each session and serving a hearty three-course meal for a donation of pound.Elaine Gale, spokeswoman for the project, felt Our Community Kitchen was well on the road to being a success.She said: ldquoIt is so exciting for the area and just to see where we go next. There is hard work in the next six months as we build these two new days up.ldquoWhat I really love, what comes across very clear to everybody, is that there are no barriers at all.ldquoIt is people coming together, having something to eat, and natural things happen when people come together to eat. That, for me, is really special.ldquoThere is nobody specic invited ndash no age limits or ability ndash it is just people.ldquoIt is amazing people coming together, having some food and everybody is laughing their head off and having a blast.A further pound, was awarded by the Walk With Scott Foundation.Scott Glynn, who founded the charity, visited Our Community Kitchen last month and was impressed with what was on offer.A post on their social media said: ldquoIt was such a joy to see a project in action, people from all walks of le getting together to have lunch and a blether.ldquoThe smiles as they walked in and the contentment of a full belly after they had been served by wonderful volunteers was a joy to see.ldquoNothing was a trouble, and everything was done with a smile and a kind word.ldquoIt was decided to help this project with funding and we are proud to have offered them pound,, with the provision of having a couple of themed days: a Burns lunch, a Wimbledon day, a bowling day and, of course, their Christmas dinner ideas were suggested.For more information on the group, which meets at .pm at the bowling club on Wemyss Place, email elainegale@gmail

title: east-lothian-the-backdrop-for-budding-directors-movie-at-glasgow-film-festival
story: Connect was written and directed by Marilyn Edmond and premiered at the Glasgow Film Festival on Saturday.The film, which stars Kevin Guthrie, of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Dunkirk, also features a number of East Lothian residents.Marilyn, who is originally from Prestonpans, was looking forward to the moviersquos first screening.She said: ldquoIt is really cool, amazing actually.ldquoIrsquom really excited about it and really happy the world premiere is in Scotland.Marilyn, who now lives in Glasgow, has been involved in film and television for nearly  years.She has worked as an assistant director on programmes ranging from Waterloo Road and Lovesick to Sunshine on Leith.However, Connect is her first time as writer and director, with the film also getting a second showingduring the -day festival. Both screenings are sold out.Marilyn revealed it was a tragedy that had moved her to create her first feature- film.She said: ldquoWhen I was working on one of the previous jobs, there was a guy that was an extra and he ended up committing suicide.ldquoIt just totally threw me.ldquoHe had posted on Facebook about how his le was brilliant and he was so happy and four months later he committed suicide.ldquoI was just gobsmacked with it.ldquoHe was only  and that really sticks with me.ldquoI feel his le had only just really started and I was really saddened by the news.ldquoAccompanied by all the stories in the media, it is quite a big subject.Writing on Connect began in November , with filming getting under way in May last year.That was wrapped up by November, with the film now finished and ready to be seen by the public.Thirty-seven-year-old Marilyn, who lived in North Berwick at the time of the filming, said: ldquoConnect is about a young man who is struggling and he is feeling suicidal.ldquoHe gets saved by a stranger and then is encouraged to live his le and reconnect with his family and friends ndash all the while he is battling his dark secret.Steampunk Coffee and Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware, both North Berwick, are among county locations used in the film, with Gullane Day Centre and Dunbar also featuring.There are also a handful of familiar faces as well, with Lynne Turnbull and Kenny Ainslie, who has carried boxer Josh Taylorrsquos Commonwealth super lightweight title to the ring, among those starring in the film.

title: only-17-per-cent-of-vehicles-going-to-coastal-car-parks-buying-a-ticket
story: A review of East Lothian Councilrsquos coastal car park ticket system has revealed that only  per cent of those who go there pay for a ticket.It points out that a high number of those not paying can be attributed to season ticket holders but admits: ldquoThere remains substantial leakage within the system.The review, which will be presented to the local authorityrsquos policy and performance review committee this week, says that ldquofurther measures to control parking and gather the parking charge are being considered.It does not give details of what those measures are.The council first moved towards introducing the charges in  of its beach car parks in  and finally introduced the pound a day charge in .A pound season pass is also available.The review acknowledges that the income from the car parks is well below the original estimate, when the business case suggested it would bring in pound, in its first year and by   would be generating income of more than pound,.The report to councillors revealed that since its introduction in July  to January this year the total income after VAT was pound,.Of that it was estimated pound, came from season ticket sales.However, the review also revealed that when the charges were first introduced, surplus cash generated was earmarked for coastal improvements.This changed when the council applied to bring in its own parking wardens and decriminalise parking offences in the county in .The review revealed that pound, of annual income from coastal car park charges was included in the business case for the new wardens.And it warned that this sum was now ldquocategorically necessary to ensure the future of the parking wardens which were introduced as a result, suggesting the charges could not be scrapped now, evencouncillors wanted to do that.It said: ldquo[The pound, was not originally anticipated within the original coastal car parking business case but does clearly make a positive contribution impact upon wider parking enforcement.

title: cousins-team-up-to-help-paddle-boarder-near-dunbar
story: Emergency services were called out on Saturday afternoon following reports of a paddle boarder in dficulty near Thorntonloch.Both Dunbarrsquos RNLI and Coastguard teams were involved, alongside North Coastguard Rescue Team and Civil Nuclear Constabulary.The callout marked the first time that Alan Blair, an RNLI volunteer for nearly  years, had been on a call-out alongside his cousin, -year-old Lewis Blair, who joined the Coastguard in January.UK Coastguard paged for the inshoreand all-weatherleboats at .pm after a member of the public raised the alarm.The crews launched minutes later and both boats were on scene by about .pm to begin a search.The person was spotted on rocks near Thorntonloch Beach before it was established the casualty had managed to make their own way to the shore.The paddle boarder, who had got into dficulties after being blown away from shore, did not require medical treatment.An RNLI spokesman said: ldquoStand-up paddle boarding is fun in flat water or surf and can be enjoyed by the whole family but this incident highlighted the potential risks.

title: children-settling-into-life-at-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: They celebrated their first day in the building last Wednesday.Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: "Irsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school."Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them."The more open classroom layouts area also great and very flexible for learning and play."They absolutely love the dining hall ndash itrsquos a really nice space. The whole environment is really relaxed.Parents also enjoyed tours of the school later the same day from pm to pm so they could familiarise themselves with its layout.The size and scale of new house building in the area meant that the former school at Salters Road was no longer able to meet the needs of the community.Land was secured on the east side of the town as part of the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.East Lothian Councilrsquos development partner, Hub South East, was responsible for delivering the project and appointed Morrison Construction as the contractor.The project received a pound.m grant from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Scotlandrsquos Schools for the Future programme.

title: parking-time-limit-restrictions-at-musselburghs-old-town-hall-tightened-up
story: A new Traffic Regulation Orderwas introduced on Monday. Although the location had been subject to a -minute limit in the past, the council created additional spaces to which the time restriction needed to be enforced.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe previous TRO made reference to the size and shape of the old road layout and therefore couldnrsquot be enforced following the construction of the new road layout.She said that a -minute waiting restriction would remain from St Peterrsquos Church, past Loretto School.The spokeswoman added that parking issues with motorists leaving their vehicles all day were compounded following the removal of Police Scotlandrsquos traffic warden service in  as there was little chance that vehicles would be ticketed.The council was then granted powers on January , , to carry out parking enforcement and undertook a series of reviews on town centre parking.A new parking layout, including additional spaces and new parking for bicycles has since been introduced by the Town Hall.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe restrictions were  minutes before but had been ignored as no enforcement could be carried out.ldquoThe council then got enforcement powers and a Traffic Regulation Order has brought in -minute limited waiting within the new road layout near Musselburgh Town Hall and on the section of High Street opposite.ldquoThe disabled parking spaces will also be enforced, ensuring blue badge holders can park close to a busy town centre.ldquoThe -minute restrictions will create a turnover of vehicles and stop all-day parking, which should assist the needs of businesses, visitors and residents during peak times. These timed restrictions will operate between the times of .am to .pm, Monday to Saturday.ldquoThe issue of increased car ownership is a major contribution to the parking problems found in Musselburgh and in other towns throughout East Lothian and, whilst this is a dficult problem to address, the council is committed to tackling such issues by improving the quality of transport infrastructure across East Lothian, promotion of sustainable transport options and identying opportunities to create more car parking spaces such as the new parking provision in Musselburgh High Street.ldquoIn addition the councilrsquos parking strategy includes extending and introducing residents parking schemes throughout East Lothian.

title: politicians-disappointed-with-apology-letter-from-scotrail
story: Martin Whitfield MP and Iain Gray MSP had written a letter to ScotRail in January outlining the problems that East Lothian constituents were facing after complaints of late trains and too few carriages.ScotRail responded by saying: ldquoWe know that train performance hasnrsquot been good enough in recent months and I am sorry for how that has impacted our customers.ldquoWhen the railway doesnrsquot work as it should, it causes immense inconvenience and disruption for those who rely on us to get to work, or to see family and friends.ldquoThe level of cancellation has reduced steadily over the past month and we will continue to cut cancellations to improve the service.ldquoAs more staff are trained, our performance is improving, and our most recent performance results continue to show an improvement.Both Parliamentarians have branded this letter ldquodisappointing, with Mr Gray saying: ldquoEast Lothian rail users are rightly fed up with ScotRailrsquos litany of excuses and hollow apologies for their ongoing service failures.ldquoActions always speak louder than words. I will not let up in highlighting the problems experienced by constituents and demanding change until we see sustained improvements in the way ScotRail delivers local services.Mr Whitfield added: ldquoOnce again, ScotRailrsquos reply to our service challenge says all the right things about delivering more staff and investing in new and upgraded trains to improve performance.ldquoThe problem is that we have heard it all before, but things never seem to get better.

title: fresh-bid-for-houses-new-clubhouse-and-course-at-dunbar-golf-club
story: Between  and  new houses could be built on two sites next to the -hole golf course, as well as a new clubhouse, a new nine-hole course and practice facilities.The proposals come  years after the club applied to East Lothian Council to develop a new clubhouse, nine-hole golf course, golf academy and driving range, short practice facilities, greenkeepersrsquo shed, housing and hotel to complement the existing course.In October , the scheme was given the green light.Now, a fresh application has been made by Dunbar Golf Club and CALA Management Ltd.The majority of the homes would be built around the existing Deer Park Cemetery, to the south-east of much of the existing golf course.A smaller number of houses is earmarked for land at the current clubhouse, off Golf House Road.Plans suggest that the nine-hole course would be created opposite the housing development being built off Bowmont Terrace.New documents lodged with the councilrsquos planning department, referencing the previously approved plans, state: ldquoThis permission also included a Section  legal agreement which seeks to control the timing of the delivery of new homes alongside the delivery of the new clubhouse and associated facilities, commits the golf club to contributions towards education provision, as well as a commitment to a collaborative approach in promoting the site for a future hotel development [and as per the masterplan].ldquoAs Dunbar Golf Club undertook further work, including marketing the site under the terms of the planning permission, it became clear that the layout proposed in the masterplan accompanying the planning permission in outline did not reflect the best option for future development, mostly with regards to the proposed mix of housing and the balance of the quantum of development between the clubhouse site and Deer Park. Clear feedback highlighted that more units should be proposed at Deer Park, with a limited development of larger homes on the existing clubhouse site.ldquoIn detailed discussions with East Lothian Council, it was agreed that fresh planning permission would be required. Given the size of the site and scale of development, it is considered a major development and therefore triggered the requirement for this formal pre-application consultation process.A public exhibition is to take place on April  at the Dunmuir Hotel, -pm, to reveal the new plans to the public for the first time.The number of houses planned are estimated to be between  and , compared to  in the previous application. The golf club will also maintain a site for potential future hotel development. Councillors Norman Hampshire, Paul McLennan and Sue Kempson, who represent the town, will also be made aware of the plans, as will the townrsquos community council.Dunbar Golf Clubrsquos East Links has played host to many national and several international championships, as well as being a final qualying course for the Open when it is played at Muirfield. The club was founded in .

title: musselburgh-woman-taking-her-dog-to-debut-at-crufts
story: Lorraine Murtagh, , of the townrsquos Delta Drive, and dog Inca are part of the Scottish team competing in the rally competition at Crufts.Rally, the latest dog sport to be recognised by the Kennel Club, involves the dog and handler working as a team to navigate a course featuring  to  exercises.Each course is dferent and there are more than  exercises in rally, including stationary tasks, recalls, jumps, retrieves and cone weaves.Lorraine is entered at level two in the Inter-regional Rally Competition, one of six competitors in the Scottish team at the NEC in Birmingham event next Thursday .The Inter-regional Rally Competition at Crufts features seven teams: Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regions. Last year, the Scottish team finished third.Lorraine got involved in rally just six months ago, having enjoyed other dog sports, and focused Inca is also proving a natural with her love for learning new things.Lorraine, who has five dogs ndash three springer spaniels and two Border collies ndash runs her own dog-walking business, Waggy Walks Edinburgh.She said: ldquoInca is a five-year-old English springer spaniel whom I rescued at just over a year old. I got her from the Dog Aid Society.ldquoShe is the sweetest, most affectionate dog and, at home, loves nothing more than cuddling on the sofa.ldquoOn walks she loves to run and explore, and is always up for an adventure. Inca also loves to work and will turn her paw to anything I ask of her.ldquoShe is always happy to learn and, although we are both new to rally, we are really enjoying learning new skills together. Inca and I also train and compete regularly in flyball and in agility, where she currently competes at Grade . We also do a little Canicrossto keep us busy.ldquoInca is a joy to work with and a wonderful friend.ldquoI am really excited about my first time competing at Crufts ndash I canrsquot wait.Tom Mather, Crufts chairman, said: ldquoCrufts offers something for everyone and this year looks like being no exception.ldquoVisitors to the show will be able to see dogs and their handlers taking part in a iety of activities and displays and we would urge anyone looking to buy a puppy to visit the ever-popular Discover Dogs area where they will be able to meet the breeds up close.ldquoWe feel honoured to welcome dogs from a wider iety of breeds than ever before, representing all corners of the globe.ldquoThe fact that people travel far and wide to enter this prestigious event proves that it really is the worldrsquos greatest dog show.Crufts runs from March  to . Nearly , dogs will compete for best in show, including , dogs from overseas. Italy has the most entries from overseas with  dogs followed closely by France .For more information, visit crufts.org.uk

title: more-than-30-jobs-to-be-created-as-dunbar-asda-extension-approved
story: The extension, which will be to the north of the existing building, is expected to see the store stock more homeware products and also see the launch of a home shopping service.The supermarket giant submitted plans to East Lothian Council before Christmas. Now planners have given the scheme the green light, with no objections from the public.A spokesman for Asda told the Courier: ldquoWersquore delighted with the outcome.ldquoThese plans represent a signicant investment into our Dunbar store and will improve the range of goods on offer and help bring Asdarsquos famously low prices to more people, as well as providing new job opportunities.It is not yet known when work will start on extending the Spott Road store or how long the construction work will take. Currently, the store, which opened about  years ago, has a floorspace of about ,m, with the extension adding a further m to the building.A total of  parking spaces will be lost but it is felt that the remaining  spaces will be adequate because the increase in home deliveries will likely offset the reduction in customer trips to the store.The home delivery service will see four vans operating from the store.One van is expected to make four deliveries per day, with the remaining three doing half that number.Dunbar Community Council backed the plans, while Dunbar Tradesrsquo Associationhad reservations but vowed to keep working to ensure the success of the townrsquos High Street.The planning officerrsquos report noted: ldquoThe proposed extension would sit comfortably on the side of the existing building and would not harmfully disrupt its architectural form and appearance.ldquoIt would be physically and visually well contained to the side of the existing building and would not be an overdevelopment of it.ldquoThe proposed extension would be a subservient and complimentary addition to the existing building and would not appear intrusive or incongruous in its setting.

title: breathing-space-for-the-hollies-day-centre-after-120000-boost
story: The grant, for a three-year period, has been announced, much to the delight of manager Liz Shannon.She told the Courier: ldquoThe dference the award from The National Lottery Community Fund will make to the members and customers of the Hollies is immeasurable.ldquoIt will give a breathing space for the near future.ldquoIt will allow us to not only maintain existing services but expand what we already offer the elderly population of Musselburgh and surrounding areas.ldquoThis includes providing entertaining and structured activities for the over-s in a warm, safe and comfortable environment.ldquoWe also want to help prevent social isolation and encourage social interaction by continuing to provide a place for people to meet friends and make new ones.Maureen McGinn, chairperson of The National Lottery Community Fund Scotland, said: ldquoI am delighted that Hollies Day Centre SCIO has been successful in securing a grant from The National Lottery Community Fund.ldquoThe award will make a big dference where it is needed most and I wish the Hollies Day Centre every success as it goes on to develop and expand its project for the benefit of their local community.Ms Shannon said that the lottery funding would help with services such as staffing costs and the centre would also continue to fundraise.The good news follows a dficult time for the cash-strapped Hollies, which was the victim of a break-in before Christmas when a safe was stolen from the High Street premises.But supporters and members of the public rallied round, with donations from ious sources, including Scott Glynn of the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation, who presented a cheque to the centre for pound, to replace the cash stolen in the safe.Staff and volunteers also celebrated the success of their pound, bid for funding from the Robertson Trust, which aids organisations working in Scotland and a pound, leline from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund to keep its services going in the lead-up to Christmas.The Hollies, which received an pound, grant from East Lothian Council last year, has received its final instalment of more than pound, which takes it to the end of the financial year in March.Ms Shannon said that the centre was still in talks with the local authority over provision of its services in the future.Martin Whitfield, East Lothian MP, visited the Hollies recently to meet staff, volunteers and members, and congratulate them on their lottery funding boost.He said: ldquoThe Hollies Day Centre is a much-loved community facility which does an amazing job for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI was pleased to visit the centre to meet staff, volunteers and some of the local people who use its services and congratulate them on their latest success in securing this lottery funding.ldquoItrsquos great news for the centre and will help it to keep making a positive dference for older people in Musselburgh.ldquoI want to congratulate Liz and her team, and thank them for everything they do.Ms Shannon added: ldquoThe Hollies staff and volunteers were delighted to welcome Mr Whitfield.ldquoHe enjoyed a tour of our fabulous community resource in the centre of Musselburgh.ldquoWe hope that he will visit again soon so we can keep him abreast of all the new and exciting activities taking place at the Hollies.

title: top-jockey-peter-scudamore-helps-launch-new-replay-cards-at-musselburgh-racecourse
story: On-hand to support the initiative last week was eight-time champion jockey Peter Scudamore MBE and local MP Martin Whitfield.Mr Scudamore joined local Sporting Memories groups, volunteers and other local racing representatives to talk about his time as a jockey and trainer and share his memories and stories. He also took part in a question-and-answer session involving group members.The launch at Musselburgh, Scotlandrsquos second biggest racecourse, was held by Sporting Memories in partnership with Racing Welfare Scotland and Racing Together. It ran simultaneously with another launch event at Palace House, The National Heritage Centre for Horseracing  Sporting Art, at Newmarket.The sporting aid memory cards feature the great and the good of horseracing throughout history and were compiled with the assistance of Racing Welfarersquos Malton-based welfare team to support older people living with dementia, depression and loneliness. The cards have an image of a sporting legend on the front and some information about their achievements on the back.Sporting Memories produces a number of resources and materials to inspire and promote reminiscence, which are then available for third-party organisations to buy to utilise at their own events.Chris Wilkins, co-founder and director of Sporting Memories Network, said: ldquoThe Sporting Memories Foundation in England and Scotland uses sports reminiscence to engage isolated older people living with conditions such as dementia, loneliness and depression.ldquoOur club members, who meet on a weekly basis in locations across the UK, are brought together through a shared love of sport, and enjoy using our replay reminiscence cards that help trigger memories and conversation.ldquoWe have already produced a range of replay cards which reflect a wide selection of sports, and we are now delighted to launch our latest set on racing, which will help to trigger memories of watching or participating in horseracing.ldquoThemes for the cards were suggested by members of our Racing Welfare Sporting Memories Club at Malton and reflect some of the great jockeys, horses and courses that together represent some of the best and most enduring memories of racing.ldquoImages can be very powerful in helping prompt memories and stories which, particularly for people living with dementia, can otherwise remain locked away and untold. Our aim is to unlock those stories and together celebrate some wonderful racing memories.ldquoWe couldnrsquot deliver our work without the support of volunteers and we are always looking for other sports fans who might be interested in supporting the fun and fulfilling activities that take place in our weekly clubs. Information about our clubs and volunteering opportunities can be found at our website thesmfMP Mr Whitfield said: ldquoI was delighted to attend the launch of the Sporting Memories Foundationrsquos new racing replay cards in Musselburgh.ldquoThese cards are another great resource from Sporting Memories, which has an extensive range of sporting memory aids. Listening to Peterrsquos stories and the memories they evoked in others made it clear what a valuable tool they can be for those living with dementia.ldquoI commend Sporting Memories and Racing Welfare on this welcome initiative and their other activity supporting older and vulnerable people.

title: in-pictures-our-lady-of-loretto-youth-players-back-to-the-80s-show
story: The cast of young performers, aged  to , were delighted with the support from audiences over the three days of the recent production.Hit songs by a range of stars from the s ran through the show, which told the story of Corey Palmer, played by Peter Lally, remembering his last year in high school.The music included Footloose, Irsquom Gonna Be , Girls Just Want To Have Fun, Hey Mickey, Shot Through The Heart, Video Killed The Radio Star, Kids In America, The Final Countdown, Total Eclipse Of The Heart and Walking On Sunshine.The -strong cast included: Tfany Houston, played by Kirsteen Brownlee Mr Stevie Cocker ndash Georgio Michalakis Ms Sheena Brannigan ndash Anna Scott Cyndi Gibson ndash Jorgey Scott-Learmonth Fergal McFerrin ndash Jamie Fleming Michael Feldman ndash Luke Davidson and Eileen Brannigan ndash Eva Hills.Jill Alexander, an audience member, took to Facebook to praise the show, saying: ldquoWent to this show on a girlsrsquo night out with no expectations. Was totally blown away by this young grouprsquos talent, enthusiasm and professionalism. What a fabulous group with a shed-load of stars. Absolutely loved it.On the last night, the cast thanked Lorna Stewart, who stood down as chairperson after ldquomany years of incredible support to the group. She has been involved with OLOLYP for  years, which began as parent helper when her children were members of the group. She has given assistance through the committee and at shows, serving as chairperson for the past seven years.A former Musselburgh resident, she has now moved to Fe but continued to travel back to the Honest Toun to support OLOLYP.The young performers also paid tribute to the crew, sponsors and Brunton staff for their help in staging the show.The Musselburgh-based group now take a break until August, when they look forward to welcoming new members, aged  to , to join for their new show. They meet at Our Lady of Loretto Church Hall at pm every Sunday from late August.Anyone interested should email lorettoyouthplayers@hotmail or search for lsquoOur Lady of Loretto Youth Playersrsquo on Facebook.

title: 5000-donation-saves-dunbars-stone-stacking-championships
story: The European Stone Stacking Championships brought , people to the townrsquos coastline last April but it was feared that the competition might be cancelled this year due to a lack of funding.But James Craig Page, who co-organises the event, which is now celebrating its third year, was pleased to say the event would now be going ahead.He said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted, it is amazing.ldquoOf course, it was a worrying time just down to a lack of finance and whether it would go forward, but now it is going ahead.ldquoSomeone has come in and sponsored the event.Mr Page had previously told the Courier that cancelling the event, which offers a place at the World Stone Stacking Championships in America to the champion, was the ldquoworst-case scenario.However, thanks to a pound, donation from ldquoa private inidual, who wishes to remain anonymous, the event will once again take place on Dunbarrsquos shoreline.Further donations have also been received, with the event expected to cost about pound, to put on.Competitors from throughout Europe are expected to travel to East Lothian ahead of the two-day competition, which takes place on April  and .Stone stacking is an increasingly popular pastime which sees practitioners spending hours meticulously balancing rocks and stones, in sometimes unbelievable and unlikely ways, on top of one another.The competition brings together a community of stackers from across Europe.Mr Page added: ldquoIt is the most ancient art form that there is.There will be four inidual competitions at the event: the most stones balanced, the most artistic stone stack, the junior championship and the overall stone stacking champion.The first competition on April , from am to pm, is at rocky Eye Cave Beach, below Dunbar Sea Cadet hall.Competitors face the challenge of balancing as many stones as possible vertically, with last yearrsquos winner managing to balance  stones.This is followed by the balance against the clock adult competition at pm, where competitors have to balance the most stones in a three-minute challenge.The following day, adults are given three hours to create anything from stone or found objects in the artistic competition, which starts at noon.There are further competitions for youngsters, with more information at stonestacking

title: ministers-defend-mays-16bn-brexit-bribe
story: The money, which will be spread over six years, is a ldquodesperate bribe, shadow chancellor John McDonnell claimed.But Communities Secretary James Brokenshire said the money would be ldquotransformative and was not conditional on support for the Prime Ministerrsquos Withdrawal Agreement.Mrs Mayrsquos efforts to make the deal more palatable to hardline Brexiteers have hit a setback, according to a report in the Daily .Attorney General Geoffrey Cox has dropped attempts to secure key demands for a unilateral exit mechanism from the backstop or a time limit for it, according to the newspaper.The DUP and the Tory European Research Grouphave made it clear they will not support the PMrsquos Withdrawal Agreement in crunch Commons votes without such legally binding measures.I woke fuming. Tories have slashed many billions from budgets of poorest councils since   now they want us to feel grateful for the pittance they intend to dole outover six years. Its corrupt, patronising, pathetic. All to appease the Brexit monster.mdash Chris BryantMarch , Launching the new pound. billion Stronger Towns Fund package,Mrs May said: ldquoFor too long in our country prosperity has been unfairly spread.ldquoCommunities across the country voted for Brexit as an expression of their desire to see change ndash that must be a change for the better, with more opportunity and greater control.ldquoThese towns have a glorious heritage, huge potential and, with the right help, a bright future ahead of them.Mr McDonnell branded the initiative a ldquodesperate bribe.He said: ldquoThis Towns Fund smacks of desperation from a Government reduced to bribing MPs to vote for their damaging flagship Brexit legislation.But Mr Brokenshiretold BBC Radio rsquos Today programme that the money was not linked to getting the deal through.ldquoThis funding is there regardless of the outcome, but obviously we want to see a deal happening, we believe that is what is in the best interests of our country.ldquoBut there is no constitutionality in that sense.Labour MP for Stoke Central Gareth Snell said: ldquoThe entire allocation for the West Midlands over four years is less than the total value of cuts faced by Stoke-on-Trent City Council alone over the same period.The entire allocation for the West Midlands over four years is LESS than the total value of cuts faced by Stoke-on-Trent City Council alone over the same period.This is a huge disappointment. https:t.co JZOVQnPqmdash Gareth Snell MPMarch , Luke Pollard, who represents Plymouth Sutton and Devonport, scorned the pound million earmarked for towns in the South West, pointing out that it was around the same amount as the settlement agreed with Eurotunnel over the Brexit ferries ldquoshambles, adding: ldquoWhat a pathetic mess.Rhondda MP Chris Bryant said the money ndash for English regions ndash was ldquocorrupt, patronising, pathetic and ldquoall to appease the Brexit monster.Of the pound billion being allocated using a needs-based formula, the North West gets pound million, the West Midlands pound million, Yorkshire and the Humber pound million, the East Midlands pound million, the North East pound million, the South East pound million, the South West pound million, and the East of England pound million.Another pound million will be available through a bidding process to communities in any part of the country.Meanwhile, the Attorney General is set toto Brussels this week for more talks on the backstop following the reports that he has abandoned key Brexiteer demands.Asked about the Dailyreport, Mr Brokenshire said: ldquoThe Attorney General continues with his work to ensure that we get legally binding changes to ensure that we are not locked in the backstop.He said Mr Cos would be ldquoback to Brussels this week to continue the discussions to make sure that we can get those legal changes.The Attorney General is reported to be focusing on securing an enhanced ldquoarbitration mechanism that allows the UK or the EU to provide formal notice that the backstop should come to an end.But Brussels is said to beresisting demands for an ldquoindependent arbitration , outside the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.The ERG has set out three tests by which they will judge Mr Coxrsquos efforts to secure changes to the backstop.The group wants a legally binding, treaty level arrangement the language must not just simply reiterate the temporary nature of the backstop and there ldquoneeds to be a clear and unconditional route out of the arrangement.DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds said his party must see legally binding and treaty-level changes to the Withdrawal Agreement regarding the backstop in order to support it.He told BBC Radio rsquos Westminster Hour: ldquoWe need something which, whatever its legal form, has legal binding effect and which changes the current meaning of the Withdrawal Agreement.ldquoAnd which makes clear that it cannot be indefinite, and it cannot be a trap both for the United Kingdom generally and for Northern Ireland in particular.

title: financial-watchdog-to-crack-down-on-300m-car-credit-overcharging
story: The Financial Conduct Authoritysaid it is considering changes to the way in which commission works after uncovering ldquoserious concerns about the way lenders are choosing to reward car retailers and other credit brokers.It found that the widespread use of commission models, which allow brokers discretion to set the customer interest rate and thus earn higher commission, can lead to ldquoconflicts of interest which are not controlled adequately by lenders.This can lead to customers paying signicantly more for their motor finance, the FCA said, and is costing car buyers more than pound, a year, or pound million collectively.Jonathan Davidson, the regulatorrsquos executive director of supervision, said: ldquoWe found that some motor dealers are overcharging unsuspecting customers over a thousand pounds in interest charges in order to obtain bigger commission payouts for themselves.ldquoWe estimate this could be costing consumers pound million annually. This is unacceptable and we will act to address harm caused by this business model.ldquoWe also have concerns that firms may be failing to meet their existing obligations in relation to pre-contract disclosure and explanations, and affordability assessments.ldquoThis is simply not good enough and we expect firms to review their operations to address our concerns.The FCA is assessing its options for intervening in the market, including strengthening existing rules or other steps such as banning certain types of commission model or limiting broker discretion.

title: glasgow-school-one-of-the-last-private-girls-secondaries-in-scotland-to-close
story: Craigholme School, on the South Side, will shut its doors in August after being unable to resolve financial dficulties.Last year, the school joined forces with Kelvinside Academy, in the West End, in a bid to survive, but under a formal merger the school will now close in August.All pupils will be transferred to Kelvinside to complete their secondary education, although the fate of staff is more uncertain.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesTeachers may face redundancies unless new positions can be found at Kelvinside.The primary school at Craigholme, which accepts both boys and girls, will remain open as a feeder school for Kelvinside.The closure comes at a dficult time for private schools with steadily falling pupil rolls across the sector following the financial crash of .Since then fees have risen by more than  per cent, with the average annual cost to families climbing from some pound, to its current figure of around pound,. Fees at Craigholme topped pound, a year.The closure also marks another blow for single sex education in Scotland. There are now only four private girlsrsquo secondary schools left and one in the state sector.Craigholme hit the headlines in  when it emerged former pupil Aqsa Mahmood had dropped out of university to join Islamic State in Syria, where she was believed to have married an ISIS fighter.Read more of todays top Glasgow storiesDonald Wilson, chair of the board of governors at Kelvinside Academy and Craigholme School, said the closure of the senior school would now follow the merger.Mr Wilson confirmed pupil numbers at Craigholme had dropped signicantly in recent years, while the impending impact of the Barclay Review, which will see removal of business rates relief, and other financial pressures, presented signicant challenges to all independent schools in Scotland.It has not yet been decided whether the facilities and land owned by the school will be sold off or retained for use by Kelvinside.Craigholme was founded in  by Jessie Murdoch as Pollokshields Ladiesrsquo School. The school had forty pupils on the roll and was housed at Dalziel Drive in a villa named Craigholme.The schoolrsquos name was changed after the First World War to Craigholme School. Recent expansion has included a pound million PE facility on the schoolrsquos playing fields at Pollok Park.In recent years pupil rolls have fallen. In   there were nearly  pupils at the school, but this fell to  in   and  in   and  this year.Read more of todays top Glasgow stories

title: the-ultimate-packing-list-for-2019
story: Read on for our list of the best and most efficient things to pack no matter where in the world you are getting away to this year. Whether you are a sun worshipper, a continent hopper or a snow seeker try out these tips and tricks to get your packing down to a fine art.*On some occasions, we earn revenue from content. This commercial content is compiled via expert opinion. Clicking on certain hyperlinks within this article will redirect you to a rd party.The BasicsWe are all guilty of packing much more than we need when it comes to holidays ndash does anyone  feel the need to pack enough underwear so that you could wear three pairs a day and still have some spares Get ready to go Credit: PixabayA good rule of thumb to keep in mind when packing minimally is that  of an item is the most that you will need when you have access to washing facilities .Look up packing lists, and you can easily get overwhelmed. Before you e into all the details, remember that what you need can be easily broken down into six categories:Tricks to Pack Like a ProBefore you start pulling all your favourite clothes out of your wardrobe and throwing them into the nearest suitcase, take a moment to try these packing hacks that will save you space and help you get the most out of even the smallest bag.What will you take  Credit: Lum, PixabayWhat to take to sunny spotsIf you are hitting the beach or looking to soak up the rays on a sun holiday* keeping cool and looking stylish are often top of the list.While itrsquos tempting to take only shorts and skimpy t-shirts donrsquot forget to take some long sleeved options in both tops and bottoms- they are ideal for protecting you or giving you a break from the sun, not to mention thwarting annoying insect bites.Hit the beach Credit: Pexels, PixabayA well-packed suitcase should have:The big one to remember when heading away to soak up some sun is, of course, to bring plenty of sunblock with you!Remember to apply it to ALL exposed skin nothing will set you apart from the crowd quite like having sunburn in the exact pattern of that funky nettop that you thought would be the ideal way to keep cool.Getaways to colder climesGet smart when yoursquore packing for cold weather and give serious thought to what you can wear rather than pack. Large jackets, chunky scarfs and heavy boots take up so much space in a suitcase that you are better off wearing them while travelling instead and just popping your coat in the overhead bin.Be prepared fro colder weather Credit: Stock Snap, PixabayMake sure to pack:Thermals are a le saver when it comes to making the most of limited packing space. A thermal vest and long johns will instantly transform almost any outfit into one fit for colder climes with minimum fuss.Weekend AdventuresMake the most of a long weekend with a trip away from your usual haunts. When it comes to packing for short term trips less is more.Where will your weekend take you  Credit: Roger Yo Santos Dias, PixabayBeing away for only a few days means you can easily plan out what you are going to wear on each day. It is also the best way to ensure you donrsquot overpack.Make sure to pack:If you are looking to save space when packing for a weekend getaway bear in mind that basic toiletries are often available at hotels. Alternatively, get your hands on refillable travel size bottles* so you only end up taking what you need instead of that massive sized bottle of shampoo!Time to enjoy your holidayNow that you have your packing planned out itrsquos time to get back to the serious business of deciding what you are going to get up to during your next adventure!Get out there and see the world Credit: Hans, PixabayWill you be heading out to tick off sightseeing spots , or is it going to be all about taking some rest and relaxation on this trip However you decide to spend your getaway, follow these packing tips, and you will be perfectly prepared!

title: who-are-scotlands-funniest-60-people
story: Lubna KerrWho the heck is Lubna Kerr  Pharmacist or comedian Pakistani or Scot Weegie or Edinburgher  Kerr is all those things, and her current show is a hilarious exploration of the hot political topic of identity. Where is she really from  Ask heryou dare. Just dont expect a straight answer ...Lubna Kerr, Where Are You Really From , Yesbar, March  Christopher Macarthur-BoydFor the past few years the buzz on the Scottish stand-up scene has been that Macarthur-Boyd is the future ndash androgynous, boyish, at home with getting laughs out of themes of mental health, masculinity and loneliness. The -year-old boy-man hails from the East End of Glasgow and jokes that he lives up to its tough image. ldquoYou wouldnrsquot want to bump into me in a dark alley ndash because yoursquod feel guilty about leaving me there. Watch this space.Christopher Macarthur-Boyd, Home Sweet Home, The Stand, March  Work In Progress, The State Bar, March  Richard GaddIn  Richard Gadd won the Edinburgh Comedy Award for his painfully honest and revealing show Monkey See, Monkey Do, about toxic masculinity and his own experience of sexual assault. Wrong, Frank. So wrong.REFUSAL TO BE CONSTRAINED: If Billy Connolly once had to battle with an inferiority complex, being told he was useless by the aunt he lived with, he did a very good job of hiding it as his career rolled on. If anyone every bothered to tell him he could never become a playwright, he certainly didnrsquot listen.If anyone mentioned he couldnrsquot become a pop star, that too fell on deaf ears and he appeared on Top of The Pops several times with pastiches of Tammy Wynettersquos DIVORCE and the Village Peoplersquos In The Navy. .What was also apparent was Connolly wasnrsquot afraid to cause political upset, to create ide, at one time describing the newly devolved Scottish government as ldquoa pretendy wee parliament. The man who at one time owned homes in Aberdeenshire, New York and Malta, believed himself to be a citizen of the world. And somehow he got away with his critiques because, well, he was above it all.SOCIAL CHAMELEONISM: Connolly has been able to adapt to and fit in to a iety of worlds. His film career brought him into the orbit of the showbiz greats, the likes of Robin Williams and the Pythons, but far from feeling out of his depth, the Scot not only thrived but fed on his new source material. He discovered being Glaswegian could be a bonus. He made Glaswegians, for the first time, believe something very positive could come out of a housing scheme.WRITING: But itrsquos his comic writing that confirms the manrsquos genius. Aged , he moved to the Glasgow housing scheme, Drumchapel. He said later, ldquoDrumchapel is a housing estate just outside Glasgow. Well, itrsquos in Glasgow, but just outside civilisation. His similes are close to perfect. After appearing on the same bill as Elton John in the States in , the Scot was hit on the head with a pipe. ldquoThey made me feel as welcome as a fart in a spacesuit, he said later.HErsquoS A VARIETY ARTIST: While Connolly could come up with Chic Murray like aphorisms ndash ldquoMarriage is a great invention ndash but then so is the bicycle repair kit, or brilliant parodies such as the Crucixion, he has never been afraid to bend towards the Bernard Manning ldquoIf women are so bloody perfect at multi-tasking, how come they canrsquot have a headache and sex at the same time. Or how about: ldquoA biker goes to the doctor with hearing problems. lsquoCan you describe the symptoms to me rsquo lsquoYes. Homer is a fat yellow lazy b****** and Marge is a skinny bird with big blue hair!AND A PSYCHOLOGIST: Connolly offers big performance. No Rich Hall -side-of-mouth-jokes. He doesnrsquot just tell you a funny story. He throws it right onto your face. But he also understands and highlights the fragilities and complexities of the human condition, revealed with his line, "Never trust a man, who when left alone with a tea cosey doesnt try it on." Even his throwaway comments ldquoBigotry is a hobby in Glasgow canrsquot fail to resonate.SELF-DEPRECATION: He can be in your face and seemingly confident but knows his limits and when to rein it in. Connolly, for example, points out he is usually killed off in the first  minutes of his movies. But he can act as he revealed in Queen Victoria biopic Mrs Brown, a perfect vehicle for his ability to switch from aggression to tenderness in the flick of an eyelid. But itrsquos also hard to see past his deliciously quixotic role in  dark comedy What We Did On Our Holiday.HErsquoS A SALESMAN: Connolly has sold Glasgow to the world. Okay, it wasnrsquot a shortbread tin version of his hometown, more a rusty Spam tin, with bits of stale meat still inside, but he never, ever failed to make it funny. Where Joycersquos Ulysses transformed the image of Dublin from a backwater to a metropolis, Connolly too has sold his hometown, its colour and vibrancy, its humour as dark as a boilermakerrsquos overalls.HErsquoS A FIGHTER: Billy Connolly offers up the black comedy line, ldquoIrsquove got Parkinsonrsquos Disease. And I wish tae f*** hersquod take it back. But at the same time Sir Billy is entirely aware of the impact hersquos had on so many people. And so he should be. "Im very lucky in as much as I made a bit of a mark, and you think, well, I must have done something right.The Glasgow International Comedy Festival runs from March -.
