title: paul-hutcheon-scottish-labour-needs-a-leader-not-a-follower
story: The th century Russian novelistrsquos wise words could apply to Scottish Labour, perhaps the most dysal brood in UK politics.Richard Leonard heads to Dundee this week for his second party conference as leader. He wants to pitch himself as a potential First Minister and present his party as a united family to voters.Gary Smith, who leads a trade union that employed Leonard for more than  years, appears not to have been sent the harmony memo.According to Smith, Scottish Labour has failed on Brexit and been weak on anti-Semitism. Damningly, he says Leonardrsquos strategy of ldquoriding on the coat-tails of Jeremy Corbyn wonrsquot work. In boxing terms, Smith has delivered a first-round knock-out.His analysis also happens to be shared by a growing body of opinion within Scottish Labour. I accept Leonard and Corbyn are close politically, but ideological similarities do not require a leader to surrender his autonomy and behave like a parrot.Brexit is his biggest failure. Leonard, much to the frustration of his MSPs and party members, has echoed Corbynrsquos Euroscepticism and opted to say as little as he can get away with on a second referendum. Both men want to strangle this option.Leonardrsquos hostility to a public vote is against the backdrop of over % of voters in Scotland supporting Remain in . Opinion polls show that backing for staying in the European Union has grown since the referendum. And yet, despite these facts, Leonard has bizarrely manoeuvred himself into the position of being the most pro-Brexit leader at Holyrood.His sleepy approach to the anti-Semitism row provides further evidence that his gut instinct is to defer to Corbyn. When the UK Labour leader resisted the full IHRA definition of anti-Semitism last year, Leonardrsquos response should have been swt and decisive.ldquoThe party should sign up to the IHRA and all the associated examples, without hesitation. We must make amends with the Jewish community, the statement should have read.Leonard instead gave a feeble interview to the BBC during which he offered warm words to Jews, but nothing . Corbyn eventually performed a U-turn and, asby magic, so did Leonard. It is clear some of his supporters believe the anti-Semitism scandal has been exaggerated to damage the Corbyn project.As a result of his back-seat leadership, Leonardrsquos fortunes are now tied to the electoral performance of Corbyn. He has failed to exercise the autonomy many of his predecessors worked so hard to extract from the UK party. His team is effectively a satellite of the Leader of the Oppositionrsquos Office at Westminster.He may also regret trying to use Corbyn as his meal ticket to Bute House, as there is little evidence of a ldquoJC bounce in Scotland. As Smith pointed out, although Scottish Labour made gains at the last general election, the party only put on , votes compared with the previous poll. Around , of these were in Edinburgh South, where Ian Murray was explicitly anti-Corbyn.Two rows are brewing that will inevitably fuel Labour faction-fighting. On Holyrood selections, Leonard allies want him to use his majority on the partyrsquos Executive to hand-pick List candidates for next Scottish Parliament election. Such a move would be brutal, and could inject fresh blood into a jaded group of MSPs, but it would backfireit was used to install middle aged under-achievers from the trade union movement.The partyrsquos ldquoorganisational review, led by deputy leader Lesley Laird, is the other potential flashpoint. Scottish Labour Kremlinologists see it as an attempt to restrict the power of general secretary Brian Roy and his team. Insiders say UK Labour is already micro-managing Scottish Labour finances in an unprecedented way.Leonard is a nice man. He has a big heart and was a more authentic representative of Labour values than Anas Sarwar, who he defeated for the leadership. But he is flailing and his party is heading towards another thumping defeat. Scottish Labour needs a leader, not a follower.

title: the-seuss-the-whole-seuss-and-nothing-but-the-seuss
story: IF you look back on your le yoursquoll be surprised to discover just how deeply Ted Geisel is embedded in the heart and soul of your family. For me, it started with my grandmother teaching me to read at the local library the summer before I went to primary school. She chose books by Geisel - beloved around the world under his pen name, Dr Seuss. Green Eggs and Ham, and The Cat in the Hat set me up for a lelong love affair with the written word.I taught my own children to read with Dr Seuss, and to this day my two daughters and I still read The Grinch together every Christmas Eve. Theyrsquore  and . They tell me theyrsquoll read the same books to their children, and I imagine in years to come those children reading Seuss to their own sons and daughters long after Irsquom gone.After I published my first novel, I began writing stories for my children, but I soon realised Irsquod never have the magic of Seuss - whorsquos been called the Milton, the Renoir, of childrenrsquos writing. So I began studying the le of Ted Geisel - I wanted to know what shaped this genius.Itrsquos a good time to tell his story: yesterday was Dr Seuss Day, when hersquos celebrated around the world, and Thursday is World Book Day - an excuse for children to dress up as their favourite literary characters. Unsurprisingly, the Cat in the Hat is one of the most ubiquitous outfits.Ted was a complex man, his soul could be as light as a childrsquos, yet his le - which charted the th century and took in many of its great themes such as war, wealth, race and changing social values - was often full of the pain of adulthood.He was born into a wealthy immigrant German family in the town of Springfield, Massachusetts, in , and named Theodore Seuss Geisel. Itrsquos thought Matt Groening, creator of The Simpsons, set his anarchic cartoon in a fictional Springfield in homage to Seuss. From the very beginning, Tedrsquos le was a mix of word-play and imagination. The brewery his father owned - Kalmbach and Geisel - was known locally as lsquoCome Back and Guzzlersquo, and his mother, from a family of bakers, sang weird nonsense songs to him about pies.His father helped run the local zoo, and encouraged Ted to draw the animals he saw there. Tedrsquos pictures were strange caricatures - with too many knuckles, or spindly legs. His first character came from one of these lsquozoo drawingsrsquo - a beast with ears nine foot long which he called a lsquowynnmphrsquo.His niece Peggy Owens - who was as close to Seuss as a daughter - said: lsquoHe never lost the ability to see things through the eyes of a child.rsquo That ability to retreat into a world of imagination became more important to Ted as he got older. When the First World War broke out, Ted found himself bullied by other children because of his German roots and with the coming of prohibition in peace time, the family brewery was closed.Ted was no great scholar but he excelled at English, and after school he went on to Dartmouth College. While there, he spent most of his time writing for the collegersquos magazine Jack-O-Lantern - which carried cartoons and comic stories. Classes forgotten, hersquod be found in the morning, sleeping at his editorial desk. His niece Peggy said: lsquoHe simply never stopped playing hookey from the real world.rsquoA run-in with the law over a gin party during prohibition saw him banned from the magazine. But Ted got round the punishment by writing under a nom de plume: Seuss. Phyllis Cerf Wagner - the actress, socialite and writer who married Tedrsquos publisher Bennet Cerf, and was instrumental in the shaping of the Seuss legend - said: lsquoHe took his motherrsquos maiden name, Seuss, as he was saving Geisel for when he wrote the great American novel.rsquoFor now, though, the dizzying heights of literature were to evade him. He went to Oxford University in the hope of becoming an English professor, but dropped out. He spent most of his time at Oxford doodling in his notebook - which brought him to the attention of a bright young American woman called Helen Palmer. Looking over his shoulder in a lecture, she saw one of his pictures - a flying cow - and told him he should become an illustrator. Not long after, they ed to America and married. Helen was less a muse and more a mentor - she encouraged and helped shape his work, and she brought order to his le.Ted was no party animal - he was shy, nervous in public, and liked the company of close friends not big groups, though he did love a vodka on the rocks and plenty of cigarettes - however, the strictures of adulthood were not for him. Without Helen, it was said, he wouldnrsquot have been able to balance a chequebook.Ted became a jobbing cartoonist and by now had added lsquoDrrsquo to his pen-name - an in-joke about the doctorate hersquod failed to get at Oxford. His big break came by chance. In the s, Flit was a popular brand of fly-spray. Ted drew a one-off cartoon for Judge magazine showing a medieval knight who canrsquot sleep because therersquos a dragon in his bedroom. The punch line reads: lsquoDarn it all, another dragon. And just after I sprayed the whole castle with Flit.rsquoHe was hired on the spot to do all Flitrsquos ads. lsquoThis became one of the most successful advertising campaigns in history,rsquo one of his biographers, Janet Pascal, says. Financially comfortable, Ted now turned his attention towards his lelong ambition: writing and illustrating childrenrsquos books.Ted was infamous in his family for exaggeration - he was always embellishing the truth . His first big success was more than a little autobiographical. The book lsquoAnd to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Streetrsquotells the story of a child out for a walk who imagines a fantastical adventure. A suburban afternoon becomes filled with make-believe giraffes, magicians, police - and a man with a ten foot beard.Initially, publishers turned the book down - it didnrsquot have a moral, they said - but finally it was bought and in  became a critical hit. Beatrix Potter was a fan, saying she adored lsquothe truthful simplicity of the untruthfulnessrsquo.Publicly, Tedrsquos le was on the up, but privately there was much sadness. His mother died before seeing his success, and his beloved sister Marnie drted into alcoholism and died whilst estranged from Ted. He and his we also learned they couldnrsquot have children. Ted would later invent an imaginary child lsquoChrysanthemum-Pearlrsquo and heartbreakingly dedicate a book to her. His friend and biographer Judith Morgan said: lsquoPart of his protection was to not allow himself to spend his le in grief, and perhaps thatrsquos why he found such joy in doing the outrageous books he did.rsquoHis next successful book, Horton Hatches The Egg, added the morality that Mulberry Street was seen to lack. It tells the story of an elephant, Horton, who finds an egg, abandoned by its mother, and sits on it in the hope of hatching it, in the face of threats and even the risk of being shot. lsquoShootyou must,rsquo says Horton, lsquoI wonrsquot run away. I meant what I said and I said what I meant, an elephant is faithful,  per cent.rsquoIt was a smash hit. Tedrsquos editor, Michael Frith, said: lsquoIn the hands of a gted preacher therersquos nothing more powerful than a great lesson.rsquoHorton appeared in . As war loomed, it would be seven years before Ted wrote another book. lsquoWhile Paris was being occupied by the clanking tanks of the Nazis,rsquo Ted said, lsquoI could no longer keep my mind on drawing pictures of Horton the elephant.rsquoToo old to fight, Ted enlisted and became a captain in one of the most remarkable propaganda outfits ever - the US armyrsquos First Motion Picture Unit. He worked with Mel Blanc , Chuck Jones , and Frank Caprachurning out films like Private Snafu - army slang for lsquoSituation Normal: All F****d Uprsquo - to boost the war effort.After the war, there was a social panic over the effect of TV on childrenrsquos literacy. Ted was challenged by his publisher to write a story for children learning to read using just  simple words. The limitations were tortuous but after a yearrsquos labour The Cat in the Hat was born - the story of a trickster cat who causes havoc in the lives of two young children.The book has been poured over by literary scholars. Itrsquos been subjected to Freudian analysisand to racial interpretations . To most, it simply captures the anarchy of childhood. Janet Schulman, an editor who worked closely with Ted, said: lsquoHe allowed a childrsquos imagination to guide him.rsquoTed was now re-writing the rules of how children learned to read. With Green Eggs and Ham, he reduced the number of words in the book to just  - making it a perfect primer - and was hailed as the saviour of childrenrsquos literacy, replacing stale Peter and Jane with the crazy Fox in Socks.Now the most important childrenrsquos author in the world, Tedrsquos stories became more political. The Sneetches savages American racism The Butter Battle Book mocks the Cold War The Lorax is an environmentalist fable. His politics often upset conservative America.In , after struggling with ill health, and depression over Tedrsquos affair with Audrey Stone Dimond, a friend of the family, Helen took her own le. Ted married Audrey less than a year later.Tedrsquos last book is one of his most loved - Oh, the Places Yoursquoll Go. Itrsquos Tedrsquos joyous take on le - his valediction to readers young and old. His agent, Jed Mattes, said it was lsquolike a wise grandfather sitting down and talking to a younger generationrsquo.In his last days, Ted, too unwell to make it to his bedroom, slept in his studio. He died in , just a few feet from his drawing board. After his death, the students of his old college, Dartmouth, recited his works for a full day, as a mark of respect to a man who had single-handedly shaped their childhood, and the collective childhood of us all.

title: Iain Macwhirter  28 days to go and Westminster won   t even reject no deal  let alone back a People   s Vote
story: I could give you a pious expression of naive hope. Tell you that therersquos going to be a referendum on Brexit, that the ERG are back in their box, Jezza has finally come good, and Theresa May has been put in a secure unit. But I canrsquot in all honesty agree with commentators, like the blessed Polly Toynbee, who believe we are now on the road to redemption.Yes, Labour did repeat its promise to hold a referendumJeremy Corbynrsquos ldquoworkable plan of a permanent customs union is rejected ndash as it was in one of last weekrsquos many meaningless votes. Oh, and Labour will support a referendumthere is no General Election. Anda no deal Tory deal looks likely. If, , .ButLabour really wanted to eliminate the threat of no deal, it would have moved heaven and earth to deliver the SNPrsquos motion calling for precisely that.Looking back on this dismal week, the standout, surely, is the arrant insanity of Parliament ndash a rational body of elected representatives ndash failing to take the opportunity to rule out an event which would put the army on the streets, interrupt food and medicine supplies, and cause the loss of tens of thousands of jobs.Yes, the Yvette Cooper Oliver Letwin amendmentwas endorsed by Parliament overwhelmingly, after Theresa May gave it the nod. This means that there will be an extension to Article Parliament doesnrsquot support a deal by March . Well and good. If therersquos one thing the UK Parliament is supremely good at itrsquos failing to agree.It doesnrsquot like Mayrsquos botched deal, the Norway option, EFTA or any other solution that Brussels thinks acceptable. So that means an extension is inevitable. Except that the French president Emmanuel Macron and the Brussels negotiator, Michel Barnier, have made clear that the  countries of the EU , will only contemplate delaying Britainrsquos departure from the EUit is for ldquoa purpose. Holding more meaningless votes, staging more ministerial resignations and arguing on College Green outside Parliament do not, one suspects, constitute a legitimate purpose.Still, everyone seems convinced that an extension is in the bag. This led to largely unwarranted excitement on the Remain side. With Labour calling for a Peoplersquos Voteand Theresa Mayrsquos deadline finally breached, Twitter went into orbit. Lord Adonis all but declared victory in the Battle of Brexit. Europhiles were dancing in the streets, metaphorically at least, and jeering at the nasty Brexiters who had been defeated by the forces of good. It was like the last reel of Lord of the Rings.But such triumphalism was premature. Much as I wish it were the case, there is still no majority in Parliament for a referendum. Stephen K Bush, the political editor of the New Statesman, has been counting them out and counting them back in again and he is adamant that the Labour Brexit rebels will prevent any motion for a referendum passing through Parliament. He says at least  Labour MPs are opposed. Hersquos right.ldquoRebels here is something of a misnomer since there is widespread belief that Brexit is the outcome desired by their leader. Indeed, on one interpretation of last weekrsquos events, Jeremy Corbyn has managed to find a way to secure Brexit while also appearing to support a referendum. This is because what is called the Kyle Wilson amendment.This cross-party proposal, which Labour is minded to support on March , calls for MPs to agree to Theresa Mayrsquos deal , but only on the condition that there is a referendum to validate it. Bingo. Labour can tell all its working-class Brexit supporters in target marginals that, yes, it didnrsquot block Brexit. But Jeremy can also curry favour with the Remainiacs of Islington by appearing to support a Peoplersquos Vote.Itrsquos very clever, but to my mind somewhat bonkers. Why would Labour help pass Theresa Mayrsquos deal, which Jeremy Corbyn has said is worse than no deal, would lose thousands of jobs and would lock the UK into a backstop from which it cannot escape  At least this is what he has said repeatedly in the Commons.Surely, a vote is a vote. Theresa May could legitimately say that her deal has been endorsed by Parliament, and call on Labour to campaign for it in any referendum. Not that she has the slightest intention of calling a referendum.Theresa Mayrsquos strategy is the same as it ever was: not listening, nothing has changed, take it or leave it. It pains me to say it, but the Prime Minister at least has a strategy. It is to run down the clock, while allowing the ious tribes in Parliament and in her Cabinet, to fall out among themselves.Itrsquos working. Labour is moving ever more in the direction of her deal, however much they may deny it. Parliament canrsquot agree on anything.There are tears in Cabinet and more resignations ndash  from the Government so far. But whorsquos counting  The European Research Group ndash that comically misnamed faction of extreme Brexiters ndash has reportedly split over William Rees-Moggrsquos equivocation on the Irish backstop.And while all about is chaos and acrimony, so ticks away the clock until Brexit day. Twenty-eight days at the time of writing. Goodness me, is that really the time  Yes it is. As in the film of the same name, the zombies are stirring.I accept that is an offensive way to describe Nigel Faragersquos ldquoBrexit Betrayal march from Sunderland to London. But it could get nasty on the road.What do I think will happen in the end  As Irsquove been saying in this column since Christmas, I think Parliament will block a no-deal Brexit. There will be an extension of Article , and Labour will probably end up backing Mayrsquos deal, or abstaining on it which amounts to the same thing.If Labour, by some remote chance, continues to reject Mayrsquos deal or its iants, in the meaningful vote on the inglorious twelfth, then I think MPs would still reject a referendum. There is still no majority for one, and Labourrsquos die-hard Brexiters are not for turning.Which makes the most likely option ndash about the only one Theresa May can authorise as PM under her prerogative powers ndash would be to revoke Article . Pull the plug. End it.OK, so thatrsquos wishful thinking on my part. Her Government would fall and precipitate an election. But looking at the chaos that is Brexit, and the lack of time, it seems as good a shout as any, especiallyBrussels reject a meaningless extension.If Britain canrsquot decide how to leave the EU, an extension to Article  would be pointless. The sensible thing to do would be to cancel Brexit, go away, and think again.

title: settlement-was-offered-three-years-earlier-to-glasgow-city-council
story: Stefan Cross of Action  Equality Scotland, which represents the majority of the , mainly female workers who secured the mammoth settlement in January, said he approached the council in June  with the intention of bringing an end to the long-running dispute.ldquoWe had a short meeting with [then council leader] Frank McAveety and [HR director] Robert Anderson to discuss the possibility of resolving these matters, he said.ldquoThe basis was thatthey paid our clients what we thought they were entitled to under payment protection we would end the legal proceedings.ldquoOur estimate was that it would be about pound million but we would have to very the figures as we hadnrsquot seen the pay data.ldquoThat was the nature of the discussion it was us making a presentation trying to break the log-jam and them not responding at all. We didnrsquot succeed - thank god for that.At that time, the council had won an employment tribunal case saying that a job evaluation process it had completed a decade previously was sound. An appeals tribunal, however, had ruled that its practice of protecting bonuses that had previously been earned by male staff only was discriminatory.While the women were appealing the first decision and the council the second, Mr Cross said he would have been willing to draw a line under all proceedings to settle the payment protection part only.ldquoStatistically, therersquos only a % chance of overturning a tribunal decision so we knew there was a massive risk that we would lose the appeal - it was much more likely that we would lose than we would win, he said.ldquoWe thought we wouldnrsquot win until we got to the Supreme Court, although we didnrsquot even knowwe would get the possibility to get to the Supreme Court.ldquoWe didnrsquot know we would win at the Court of Session - that was the risk we were running - but it happened to be that we got a bench that clicked.After losing both appeals the council, which passed from Labour to minority SNP control in May , agreed to settle the claims, with the poundm deal being agreed this January after a year of negotiations. To help foot the bill the local authority, which will increase council tax by % this year, is mortgaging a portfolio of properties including the Riverside Museum and SEC Armadillo, with the annual cost of servicing that debt expected to run into tens of millions of pounds.Mr McAveety and Glasgow City Council both confirmed that the informal and unminuted meeting with Action  Equality took place, although they denied that the poundm figure had been discussed.ldquoThis did not happen, a council spokesman said. ldquoRepresentatives of ActionEquality restated their position that the council should stop defending equal-pay claims.ldquoHowever, officers are clear that no offer was made and that figure was not put to the council.Mr McAveety said that while he personally would have been in favour of negotiating an end to the dispute, his hands were tied by council officials who wanted to follow legal process.ldquoSenior officials said lsquothis is in the courts and therersquos been an employment tribunal ruling that has favoured the councilrsquo, he said.ldquoThe general discussion [at the meeting] was around the issue of the number of folk that Action  Equality were representing, an observation on the role of the trade unions and, from Stefan Crossrsquos point of view, that we should try to settle.ldquoIt was left to Robert Anderson and the chief executive [Annemarie OrsquoDonnell] to deal with and I never came back [to Action  Equality] because I thought there was no authorisation from the council.The eventual bill for the local authority is signicantly higher than Mr Crossrsquos original estimate because, in addition to the number of claimants more than doubling since June , it is compensating affected workers for having their jobs undervalued as well as for not being able to share in bonuses.The poundm figure covers the period from , when the discredited pay system was put in place, to either  or , with a further settlement expected to be negotiated to cover the period from that end point to when a new system is put in place.The new scheme is not expected to be implemented until  at the earliest, with , inidual jobs having to be assessed, compared and signed off by both the council and the womenrsquos union representatives first.The staff who are part of the claim are expected to start receiving their cash in the summer, with average payments in the region of pound,.

title: bbc-documentary-george-osborne-wanted-westminster-to-run-indyref
story: The controversial idea was considered, but rejected, after Liberal Democrat Ministers insisted the rules of the plebiscite should be set north of the border.The programme also revealed that former prime minister Gordon Brown wanted half of the money raised by the No side to go to Labourrsquos standalone campaign.The first episode of a three-part documentary - Yes No ndash Inside The Indyref - will look at the events which led to the announcement of the independence vote, the role of social media, and how the teams developed their strategies.It contains exclusive interviews with the key players during the referendum, and was made by Paul Mitchell, who was behind Inside Obamarsquos White House and The Death of Yugoslavia.The first episode includes the reaction amongst senior Westminster figures to the SNPrsquos landslide victory at the  Holyrood election, which paved the way for a referendum.However, in a  meeting of the ldquoquad - the key figures in the Tory LibDem coalition at Westminster - there was a discussion on London making the key decision.Nick Clegg, who at that point was the deputy prime minister, said: ldquoI remember at that meeting, George Osborne arrived late, and said half-seriously, half-jokingly, lsquocanrsquot we just run the referendum from London  Thatrsquos what they would do in Spainrsquo.Michael Moore, the then Scotland Secretary and Lib Dem MP, told the programme: ldquoHowever he meant it, it was considered. It took people like me and others to push back and say lsquowe will have to find a solution that is made in Scotland. If we try and do it from London, we will lose.Backing up Moorersquos account, Clegg said the Government had to ldquoavoid the trap of feeding the ldquogrievance narrative that the SNP liked to play.In another section, Osborne and Brown separately recalled a meeting that included former Prime Minister David Cameron on the campaign.Osborne said: ldquoGordonrsquos idea was that the Labour party should be put in charge of the campaign and the Tory party should fund it.Brown said: ldquoI said to them lsquolook, half the money should go to the Labour campaign. Labour should have a distinctive campaign.He added: ldquoLabour was best equipped to get this message across.Osborne responded: ldquoI donrsquot think that was a pretty sensible idea, frankly.Yes No ndash Inside The Indyref will be broadcast on Tuesday at pm

title: future-shock-we-scots-should-welcome-new-creationist-theme-park-where-humans-live-with-dinosaurs
story: One of these folk is the infamous Ken Ham, creationist founder of the ldquoArk Encounter theme park in Kentucky. Ham is currently hogging American headlines due to an ongoing dispute with atheist pressure group the Freedom From Religion Foundation ndash who believe Ham is a bit of a swine. The FFRF promotes the separation of church and government ndash a rather bold endeavour in a state where Governor Matt Bevin recently declared ldquoThe Year of the Bible. Perhaps, understandably, FFRF mostly carry out their protests by way of the internet ndash you canrsquot shoot the head off an online petition, after all.The group is furious that pound million in state tax incentives have helped fund Hamrsquos creationist theme park, yet ndash to be fair ndash some state officials did try to stop these generous tax breaks after learning the hardcore creationist entrepreneur would only hire Christians. Fuelled by the stimulant of self-righteous indignation, however, Ham decided to sue the state in federal court ndash and brought home the bacon by winning his case. Impressed Kentucky politicians then saw fit to reward his indefatigable faith with another wee rebate check for . million. Praise the Lord, indeed.With the penny finally dropping that there may perhaps be some sympathetic fundamentalist mindsets on governmental boards, FFRF has now recalibrated its aim and taken direct action ndash sending letters to more than , public schools around Kentucky to highlight the mind-warping dangers of taking advantage of Hamrsquos offer of free class field trips to Ark Encounter.Certainly, the statue of a smiling diplodocus at the entrance is indicative of a wilfully ignorant and wildly subjective interpretation of the Earthrsquos four-and-a-half billion year history. Yet, where traditional theme parks such as Blackpool Pleasure Beach ultimately confirm there is no God, Ark Encounter solely exists to solidy belief in a ine creator and His miraculous six-day endeavour.A gay old timeARK Encounterrsquos piegravece de reacutesistance is, like it says on the tin, an ldquoaccurate -feet-long recreation of Noahrsquos Ark ndash complete with animatronic models of dinosaurs and humans living together in harmony, just like in The Flintstones. And Job :ndash,creationist Biblical interpretations of the word ldquobehemoth are to be believed.Yet, in a move not quite in the spirit of Christrsquos New Testament message of acceptance and love, all employees at the park are required to sign a ldquostatement of faith which explicitly prohibits them from employmenttheyrsquore ldquogay, bi, or a person who has attempted to alter gender by surgery or appearance.Itrsquos perhaps then no surprise that Ham also has a concurrent campaign to, ahem, ldquotake back the rainbow. Which was,we recall Sunday School storytime, first gted to the Earth by temperamental Old Testament tyrant Yahweh himself ndash in a plea for forgiveness after killing everyone in a pique of petulant fury at our so-called ldquosins, such as homosexuality and the like. Itrsquos certainly ironic that despite being heavily influenced by The Flintstones, Ham certainly wonrsquot ever tolerate a ldquogay old time.Jockrsquos on usSCOTS are, of course, children of the Enlightenment, sensibly secular of mind and progressively liberal enough to have earned a wee condescending chuckle at the backward beliefs of some of our American cousins.Despite all evidence to the contrary, however, many of us remain within the confines of this self-gratying bubble of ldquowharsquos like us  nonsense. The truth is, wersquore perhaps even more societally regressive than any dusty, confederate backwater in the American heartlands.In , MSP Alasdair Allan ndash who was the Minister for Learning, Science and Scotlandrsquos Languages ndash saw fit to officially respond to pressure from the militantly atheist Scottish Secular Society , boldly stating the obvious to his peers in Holyrood: ldquoGuidance provided by Education Scotland does not identy Creationism as a scientic principle. It should therefore not be taught as part of science lessons.And neither should enriching uranium yet no-onersquos banned that yet. So, perhaps with that in mind, Allan fell short of outlawing the teaching of a six-day creation period by a prankster transdimensional magician ndash adding a rather timorous postscript that any precedents of governmental intolerance would inevitably lead to ldquocalls for bans on other issues and the curriculum would risk becoming mired in legal arrangements.One wonders whether Allanrsquos a**e is still numb from such an awkward perch on the fence. His non-committal stance does, however, echo successive Scottish and UK governmentsrsquo deeply ingrained reluctance to condemn, or even recognise, the bleeding chasm of ision for which religious dogma is almost entirely responsible. Most folk free from the micro-management of thought caused by this ancient virus can clearly see its butterfly effect of societal paralysis, and on a micro scale, calcying the neurones of its host to protect itself against rival contagions ndash or any wildly idealistic notions of utopic unity and global harmony.That the sediment of fear and superstition remains the fundamental layer we build our communities and education system upon in  is bad enough, but the fact religionrsquos stagnated stench still clogs the corridors of power is surely the ultimate absurdity ndash with Scottish local authorities still being legally obliged to cower under the overriding authority of Tha Lawd on council education boards.Return of the JediITrsquoS a law that surely proves wersquore all either numbed within a collective hypnotic state or that reality truly is a simulation run by malevolent aliens ndash the absurd ruling that Scottish councils are still legally required to appoint three education committee members to represent a transdimensional creator skyspirit. Legally, all require one Catholic representative, one Church of Scotland and one ldquoother. Perhaps a Jedi would be appropriate ndash as therersquos more chance of a Darth Vader figure existing in an infinite universe than a temperamental creator with suspiciously human traits such as jealousy, fury and regret.Yet, despite the comedic costumes being a dead giveaway to their shoogly grasp on reality, the pious are somehow bestowed with entirely unearned respect and privilege in our society, particularly within the corridors of power ndash despite their myopic belief systems infecting every warped thought and utterance.Itrsquos surely right that we question why unelected purveyors of fancul fiction can operate freely from voter accountably and bear influence on how our children are educated. South Lanarkshire Councilrsquos Dr Nagy Iskander is one such presence ndash a creationist who has said that evolution is ldquoreally illogical.Incidentally, Iskander counts Ark Encounterrsquos Ken Ham as a personal friend ndash perhaps admiring how he has earned a very comfortable living by convincing the naive and desperate that his self-serving porkies are the gospel truth.And finally ...PERHAPS there really is no need to rush any official ban on teaching creationism in Scottish classrooms.It could be argued itrsquos putting the cart before the horse in a country where we still appoint believers in ancient Abrahamic superstitions to education boards ndash and continue to segregate children in accordance to parental allegiances to a supernatural entity who only ever existed in our speciesrsquo minds.At least our Kentuckian cousins donrsquot believe their omnipotent comfort blanket has any allegiance to a particular sports team. Just last week, ldquoProtestant ldquoCatholic and ldquowest of Scotland were among the highest trending terms on UK twitter.Perhaps The Flintstones has simply evolved into a social media reality show, starring yabba dabba you and me. Therersquos certainly no need to build an Ark Encounter theme park in a country populated and led by dinosaurs, already fully submerged and drowning in destructive delusions.

story: All-round extreme guy Aldo Kane, wild swimmer Calum Maclean, explorer Hazel Robertson and parkour athlete Robbie Grfith took party in the first of the Herald on Sundays Cool Conversations series.Kane, , was named the coolest person in Scotland by The Herald on Sundayrsquos Cool List last year ndash and that celebration of the best of Scotland is the basis for the new series of talks and debates.Read more:Watch: Fear, exploding lava bombs and exploring world amid climate crisisThe youngest member of our  was -year-old Robbie Grfith, who shot to fame online when he did his own free-running take on Trainspottingrsquos famous Choose Le scene.Other Cool Conversations events will bring together some of the countryrsquos coolest writers, musicians, mindfulness gurus, bloggers and creatives.You can watch highlights of the event here.

title: snp-currency-plan-based-on-economic-boom-after-yes-vote-branded-fantasy
story: The Finance Secretary said higher growth would cut Scotlandrsquos poundbn deficit and create the right conditions for a rapid switch from sterling.The SNPrsquos Growth Commissionlast year said it would be probably be at leasta decade after independence before a new currency was viable.It said Scotland would need to halve a  per cent deficit to establish market credibility, and public spending should be kept under very tight control.Critics say the prescription would essentially continue Tory austerity.But Mr Mackay, who is under pressure from SNP activists not to keep sterling, said a faster timetable was possible without austerity through stronger growth.:SNP would propose a new currency for an independent ScotlandOfficial forecast put Scottish GDP growth at around  per cent until .The Growth Commission, which Mr Mackay sat on, suggested it could take  years to reach .% and  years to reach .%.But Mr Mackay told BBC Sunday Politics Scotland that after a ldquosafe and secure transition with sterling, independence could deliver a swt GDP boost.He said: ldquoWersquove got the ambition and the commitment to have an independent currency and a process to take us there. We want to grow our economy.ldquoYes, we want to bring that estimated deficit down... Growing our economy is an alternative to austerity.ldquoWe could reduce that notional deficithellip accelerate the economic growth and move to that independent currency when wersquore able to do so, by setting out the tests that would guide us there."With the powers of independence, we can stimulate the economic growth, grow our economy, get that national deficit down.Mr Mackay and SNP depute leader Keith Brown will ask SNP members next month to vote on whether it should be party policy to establish an independent currency, and whether an SNP government should aim to complete preparations to enable Holyrood ldquoto take a decision on establishing a new currency by the end of the first term of an independent parliament.However their conference motion also says "an economic stimulus at the point of independence should be considered", meaning extra public spending or tax cuts, both of which could add to thedeficitand so delay any new currency.:Tom Gordon: SNPrsquos currency plan may please members, but not votersTory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoThis is fantasy economics from Derek Mackay and the SNP. The idea that Scotlandrsquos poundbn deficit can be halved within a few years without austerity is absurd. That would either require unprecedented cuts to public services, higher taxes and more borrowing - or more likely a toxic mix of all three.ldquoThe SNP should be focusing improving education standards, fixing our NHS and growing our economy - not obsessing about separation.Mr Mackay also said the SNP would want an independent Scotland to be in the EU, but said it was not his partyrsquos policy to join the euro.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the Scotland in Union group, added: ldquoThe SNPrsquos latest independence blueprint is a recipe for deeper and tougher austerity, which would inflict hardship on families across our country.ldquoDerek Mackayrsquos support for ditching the pound and introducing a new currency is the height of irresponsibility, and even he has been forced to admit it would be high-risk.ldquoHe is all over the place, also astoundingly ignoring that new member states in the EU must commit to joining the euro.Scottish LibDemLeader Willie Rennie said:ldquoDerek Mackay is making it up as he goes along."The Growth Commission already states that the cuts to public services would be deep for an independent Scotland."But that is not enough for the SNP - they want it faster and deeper. Brexit shows that breaking up long term economic partnerships is painful - independence would be so much worse.

title: leonard-labour-government-would-block-indyref2
story: The Scottish Labour leader confirmed thathis party won power at Westminster it would refuse to grant a lsquoSection  orderrsquo giving Holyrood the power to hold another vote.MSPs voted - two years ago for a Section  order, but Theresa May has refused to grant one, saying now is not the time to revisit the  result.Asked on BBC Sunday Politics Scotland whether a UK Labour government would take the same hardline, Mr Leonard said: ldquoWhat we said in the manesto at the  election was that there is no case for, and we would not support, a second independence referendum.Pressed on Labour ruling out a Section  order and blocking a new vote, he said: ldquoWe will not agree to a second independence referendum. Therersquos no appetite for it.ldquoA Labour government... would not agree to a second independence referendum emerging from either the Scottish Parliament or from any other quarters. There is no case for a second independence referendum.Askedthat could be undemocratic given the SNP might win the  Holyrood election on a  of having another vote, Mr Leonard said he wanted Labour to win it.Nicola Sturgeon has promised an update on the timing of another vote ldquoin a matter of weeks, and last week said she would consider working with a minority UK Labour government.Mr Leonard was also asked about searing criticism of his leadership from the head of his own union.GMB Scotland chief Gary Smith told the Herald on Sunday that Mr Leonard merely followed Jeremy Corby, and had ldquonothing coherent to say about Brexit, summing up the situation as ldquoa recipe for failure.Mr Leonard said: ldquoGary is someone Irsquove known for a long time. Therersquos always been dissent in the Labour party and hersquos reflecting a voice of dissent. But I donrsquot agree with his analysis.In a bruising interview with broadcaster Gordon Brewer, Mr Leonard was also asked why he didnrsquot show more leadership on anti-Semitism and throw offenders out of the party.He was grilled on why former MP and current Renfrewshire councillor Jim Sheridan was recently readmitted after a six-month suspension for ranting about Jews on Facebook.Mr Sheridan said he had lost respect and empathy for the entire Jewish community and their ldquohistoric suffering, because of ldquowhat they and Blairitie plotters were doing to the party.Mr Leonard said: ldquoWhat Jim Sheridan said was unacceptable and shouldnrsquot be tolerated and hersquos been reprimanded as a result of that. But I donrsquot personally get involved in the disciplinary process of the Labour party. People are elected by party members to conduct those investigations and to sit on those hearings, and they make decisions.An SNP spokesperson: ldquoThis was a catastrophic interview which confirms that, with Richard Leonard at the helm, Scottish Labour are sailing further into political irrelevance.ldquoOn independence, Leonard was all over the place ndash and Labourrsquos refusal to accept that the people of Scotland have the right to choose their own future will simply condemn them to further election defeat.Tory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoIt is clear today that Nicola Sturgeon is planning a coalition with Corbyn and will demand a second independence referendum as her price.ldquoIt is also quite clear that Richard Leonardrsquos role in all this will be to sit in the back seat and do what hersquos toldldquoMr Leonard isnrsquot prepared to take the fight to Sturgeon.ldquoHe hasnrsquot got a plan to stop a second referendum. His response on anti-Semitism shows that the Scottish Labour branch office is passing the buck instead of taking action.UK Labour was also embroiled in more problems over anti-Semitism after Lord Falconer denied he had agreed to scrutinise the partyrsquos disciplinary procedures.Party General Secretary Jennie Formby announced on Friday that the former Lord Chancellor would act as a ldquocritical independent friend on the issue, but the peer said he had yet to agree his terms, and would also discuss them this week.ldquoUndertaking the role subject to agreement being reached, he tweeted.Shadow chancellor John McDonnell denied Labour was institutionally anti-Semitic but said it ldquoclearly had a problem with a minority of members.He told Sky News the party needed to react faster and be ldquomore ruthless on occasion, adding: ldquoTherersquos blind spots on left and right - the right have been virulently, violently anti-Semitic in our community, but yes, there is an issue on the left.

title: tv-review-did-tutti-frutti-pass-the-test-of-time
story: AT a minute before half past nine on Saturday night a lot of Scots of a certain age were having feelings more mixed than a Moscow Mule. The new BBC Scotland channel was about to make history by showing a repeat.Not just any repeat, though. This was Tutti Frutti, the six-part, Glasgow-set comedy drama that disappeared into a television Bermuda Triangle in  because of musicproblems and had not been broadcast on TV since.The dramarsquos absence fed the legend. Danny and Suzi. Eddie Clockerty and Miss Toner. The music. The gallusness. The six Baftas, and none of your Scottish ones either, for this was a hit across the UK.Who are the funniest  people in Scotland Some  years had passed, and now it was coming back. Hence the mixed feelings. Tutti Frutti has been the Alpha and Omega of Scottish popular culture, a touchstone, the lodestar. Would it be as good as we remembered Fears melted away in the first seconds, courtesy of Little Richard proclaiming the finest phrase rock and roll ever gave the English language: ldquoA wop bop a loo bop a wop bam boom! The opening credits rolled and there they were again, The Majestics, the nearly made it band from Glasgow who were just about to embark on a silver jubilee tour when their lead man, Big Jazza, was killed in a crash. Just like James Dean, except Jimmy wasnrsquot on a kebab run at the time.Tutti Frutti sWriter John Byrne opened his tale where all the good ones begin, at a funeral. The mourners are about to lower the coffin when a taxi pulls up at the Necropolis and out steps Danny McGlone, Jazzarsquos younger brother, all the way from New York City. Eddie Clockerty, gents haberdasher talent agent looks at Danny and ponders whether he could take Jazzarsquos place. By the time the funeral is over and Vincenthas led The Majestics in an acapella version of Three Steps to Heaven, you knew it was going to be okay. Test of time: passed with flying colours.Before the series proper began, there was a repeat of a documentary made to mark the National Theatre of Scotlandrsquos  production of Tutti Frutti. While it unfortunately contained a huge spoiler, it also had interviews with Byrne, Richard Wilson and Robbie Coltrane, the latter saying not a day of his career went by without someone asking what had happened to Tutti Frutti.Basically, the BBC failed to get world clearance for the songs. ldquoThat shows how much confidence they had in it, said artist and playwright Byrne, who delivered the series in instalments insisting no changes be made. He would not budge, either, on Coltrane for Danny Jazza - a bold move given the young comedian was then a relative unknown.Certain things inevitably dated the piece: people using phone boxes, men calling women ldquobirds, Swiss cheese plants in West End flats. Yet everything that made Tutti Frutti sing first time around makes it work again today. Get a load of Kettles and Danny sparking off each other like Cary Grant and Katharine Hepburn. Check out the settings School of Art the glorious use of language the banter the laughs. Most of the latter are supplied by the partnership of Eddie and his PA bane of his le, Miss Toner. ldquoYoursquore on a verbal warning, McClockerty tells her. ldquoAye, thatrsquoll be right, Janice bats back.Miss Toner is pure dead Glesga, which is another thing that brings a certain moistness around the eye area - Byrnersquos obvious love of the city and its people. He is to Glasgow what Alan Bleasdale is to Liverpool and Alan Bennett to Leeds: the place is in his DNA, he ldquogets it. The first episode takes viewers up to the reformed Majesticsrsquo first gig, in a Miners Welfare Institute . The Majestics are present and correct, brothel creepers on, qufs sculpted and sideburns straight out of a carpet factory. The first set, which we do not see, has been a disaster, but now Suzi Kettles has turned up and Danny is a man transformed, belting out Great Balls of Fire and the title song. The boys are back in town, and they are about to get a new band member. Rock and roll on next week.

title: tv-7-things-you-didnt-know-about-tutti-frutti
story: Tutti Frutti was commissioned for the BBC by Michael Grade, who wanted something to compete against ITVrsquos ratings hit, Minder.The original idea was based on the story of The Poets, a Glasgow blues band.Before Richard Wilson acquired his One Foot in the Grave catchphrase ldquoI donrsquot believe it!, fans would ask him to shout, ldquoMiss Toner!Scotlands funniest peopleSome viewers in England said they could not understand the Glasgow accents. She did have, however, a Glasgow-born mother, Phyllida Law.Tutti Frutti was given one repeat before it disappeared.Is new channel magic or mince It was also shown once during the ldquomissing period - on an oil rig, for which director Tony Smith received a royalty of pound..

title: letters-if-may-has-a-mandate-then-so-has-sturgeon
story: In a democracy, it is dficult to reconcile these two positions. Has Scotland no legislative say on its own future  Are we then a ldquovassal state, of Jacob Rees-Mogg perception, andso, how do Scots establish their constitutional preferences,not by the ballot box  Mr Rennie asserts there should be a second EU referendum , without his party gaining a mandate from the electorate, parliament or even Uncle Tom Cobley.Mr Rennie also asserts, evidence-free, that ending the UK Union will be much more dficult than ending the EU Union is for the UK. But Scottish self-government will not involve a Northern Ireland-type border dispute, andScotland gains speedy access to the EU, will not involve extended trade discussions either. With much of the rest, there are international legal precedents to follow, and I am sure there exists goodwill enough to facilitate an affable parting of the ways. The nuclear issue may involve posturing on both sides, but should be easily resolved with a -year lease for Faslane and the Trident system.GR Weir, Mill Street,Ochiltree.DAVID STUBLEYcompletely ignored the main thrust of my letter of February , which focused on one of the key consequences of the massive imbalance of trade in goodsbetween the EU and the UK which has not only lost us thousands of skilled jobs but costs a net pound billion annually for the privilege. A very bad deal in every sense of the word. Rather he nitpicked on minor issues before having another go about his mistaken belief that Brexit was an ldquoimpending disaster and about the benefits of ldquoEU funding into regions and rural areas which he claimed ldquoWestminster would never have granted _ the fact that it is UK taxpayersrsquo money in the first place was not even mentioned.He also claimed ldquoin common with many Leave voters that I somehow believed the misinformation which was peddled to swing the vote. Wrong. Indeed, as a Eurosceptic I even wrote a letter arguing that people should vote Remain in order to fight the dysal and unaccountable EU along with their unfair trade practices within rather than Leave. However, the majority vote was to leave and the rest is history as they say ndash but with hindsight I must admit that my original belief that there was a chance the EU could be reformed in a meaningful way has been proved wrong by the intransigence displayed by the EU ldquonegotiators thus far.Yes, Brexit will hit us harder initially but in my view Britain will adapt much quicker than than people think and provided we take tough decisions early on we will have a much brighter future ahead of us as a global player free to do our own trade deals.Ian Lakin,Pinelands,Murtle Den Road,Milltimber, Aberdeen.Read more: Conservatives warn Sturgeon against holding new voteIT is a shame that you chose apparently to support the nonsense of those attempting to tear the UK out of the EU with your Letters Page headline ldquoThe betrayal of those who voted to leave will never be forgiven . How strange that the betrayal of the closely-similar number who voted to remain does not gain such headlines and has been persistently ignored by politicians of both major parties.Surely elected members in a Parliamentary democracy are supposed to consider the interests of both those who did not vote for them as well as their supporters  In a situation where the vote was advisory, characterised by lies, barely concealed racism and illegal funding, surely it is even more important for Members to follow this code.Dr RM Morris,Veslehaug, Polesburn,Methlick,Ellon.I UNDERSTAND the concern, disappointment and anger at the possibility of delay or another referendum of many of the  million, who out of the . million registered to vote in the  EU referendum voted to leave, and against expectation, won in a  per cent turnout.And with  per cent of the electoral  vote and  hopes clearer almost three years later I believe they are right to fear a dferent result should we have the opportunity to think again.R Russell Smith, Milton Road, Kilbirnie.MANY months ago my we and I made a pact to switch channels whenever a news broadcast or other political programme about our leaving the EU comes on.Our only indulgence has been some whimsical speculation.My we believes thatthe majority of the people of the UK had voted to remain, that would have been the end of the matter and the so-called ldquolosers would have have been told just to get on with le.I on the other hand, revert to an earlier referendum and wondera majority of the people of Scotland had voted to leave the UK and been faced with the sort of opposition orchestrated by the media and other vested interestswhat would have been the reaction of the so-called winners I suspect shersquos more clever than I am.John F Crawford, The Breakers,Victory Bouled,Lytham.AFTER a crash-out Brexit are we Scots expected to believe that a Tory dictator will instruct English companies to seek trade deals with every country in the world except an independent Scotland in the EU There is an answer to that: ldquoAye, right.Bill Kerr, Sandyknowes Road, Cumbernauld.I BEG to suggest that the Brexit fiasco has not just given us the ugly ldquoBrexit word but it now justies a revised spelling of toxic ndash talksick.Bill Clark, Grahamshill Street,Airdrie.

title: advice for supporters ahead of scottish cup game at pittodrie
story: Police Scotland officers along with partners are preparing to welcome thousands of football fans to Aberdeen for the Scottish Cup Quarter Final this Sunday.Kick off for the Aberdeen and Rangers game is at .pm and so the City Centre, Pittodrie, Aberdeen Beach and Seaton areas will be busier than usual.Police ask that fans heading to the stadium plan their journeys in advance and allow themselves plenty of extra time to get to the stadium. Match Commander Superintendent Richard Craig is encouraging everyone planning to watch the game either at Pittodrie stadium, a licensed premises or in their home to enjoy the match but to behave responsibly. He said: “It is well-documented that drinking too much alcohol can lead you to become more vulnerable to becoming involved in crime either as a victim or perpetrator. I am urging supporters to behave responsibly and be aware thatyou’re drunk you won’t be allowed entry to the stadium and you’ll miss the match. “Anyone who does become involved in disorder or any act of violence will be dealt with robustly. “Additional officers will be on duty across the North East and within the stadium on Sunday and they will be supported by specialist resources. Our officers are extremely experienced in policing football matches and will be able to offer assistance should anyone need it.“Although the new AWPRis an option for travel we would still advise all football traffic coming from South of Aberdeen to use the traditional supporters’ route into the city .“We are here to ensure the safety and security of all supporters attending the game and minimise disruption to the local community. "I would remind supporters that those entering Pittodrie will be closely monitored for possession of alcohol or pyrotechnics of any kind. It is a condition of entry to the ground that fans allow themselves to be searched and those who refuse will be turned away by the club. “We will be implementing policing operations throughout the day, including spot checks on buses and coaches travelling to the game."Superintendent Craig added: “Pyrotechnics are extremely dangerous and endanger the safety of those around you as well as your own safety. We will take action, you will be arrested.“The match is undoubtedly a big event and we are looking forward to it. title: charities hold last entries to run garioch
story: The last few remaining places for Run Garioch are held by six local charities.This year’s Run Garioch charity partners are CLAN, Chest, Heart  Stroke Scotland, The Gathimba Edwards Foundation, Friends of the Neonatal Unit, Charlie House and Inspire PTL. All six will be providing essential volunteers on race day as well as have a strong presence in the Event Village, and would also be delighted to have more sponsored runners taking on the challenge of Run Garioch on their behalf.Speaking about CLAN’s involvement at last year’s Run Garioch, Fundraising Co-ordinator Ruth McIntosh, said: “Run Garioch is one of the most popular local running events for CLAN volunteers and those running on our behalf. There’s such a great spirit and atmosphere on the day and everyone thoroughly enjoys the experience.” She added: “As charities, we really cannot thank the organisers of Run Garioch and all the participants enough for their continued support."Race Director Graham Morrison added: “Run Garioch prides itself in being a community event that benefits so many groups and organisations. We were delighted when all six charities came on board as our  partners.” “Their teams will provide us with some much needed volunteers to help ensure the event is run safely for all our runners. title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. Your dog will need a rabies vaccine with blood samplestaken  days after the jab. title: golden celebrations for couple
story: An Ellon couple have celebrated their golden wedding anniversary, marking  years together.Bill and Isobel Bonner reached the milestone on Friday, March .The couple first met at the Victoria Hall in Ellon, but Bill first dated Isobel’s sister before eventually asking his future we out.Isobel said: “My sister didn’t mind us being together, she ended up being one of my bridesmaids.”The pair were together for three years and engaged for two before marrying at Dyce Parish Church on March   when Isobel was  and Bill was .Bill originally hails from the Tarves area, and Isobel from Oldmeldrum, but the couple made the move to Ellon in January .Through the years Isobel worked at the Stoneywood paper mill before working at Ellon’s former Haldanes store on the checkouts for  years, a job that she really enjoyed.Meanwhile Bill spent time working on a local pig farm and he now works as a lollypop man for Meiklemill School, and is also a part-time janitor.The couple have two sons, Mark and Robbie, and two grandchildren, Ryan and Megan.Bill and Isobel will celebrate their anniversary with close friends and family at the weekend.Commenting on their achievement Isobel said: “It is amazing but the last  years or so have just flown past.“I am the only one in my family to have reached this anniversary.”Bill added that it felt “fantastic” to celebrate  years together.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.thesouthernreporter webimage ..! title: msp to host surgery for eu nationals amid brexit uncertainty
story: Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin will be holding a drop-in surgery for EU citizens concerned about the impact of Brexit on their settled status.It comes as the UK Government continues to negotiate its exit deal from the European Union before the expected leave date of March .Ms Martin has invited EU citizens living in her Aberdeenshire East constituency to join her at two separate events in Inverurie and Mintlaw this Saturday .Figures obtained from Spice, the Scottish Parliament’s research and information centre, show that there are around , EU nationals living and working in Aberdeen City and , in Aberdeenshire.People who want to stay in the UK must apply for settlement status through the EU Settlement Scheme.The first session will be held in Inverurie at the Garioch Community Education Centre from am till noon.The second session will be held in Mintlaw in the afternoon from pm till pm at the Macbi Centre.Commenting, Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I would encourage any EU citizens living in my constituency who have questions and are concerned about what applying for settled status means to them, to come along to the drop-in surgeries.“This is a very concerning time for everyone, not least for the huge number of EU nationals who have moved to Scotland and made our country their home.“The UK Government continues to cause uncertainty and there is a huge lack of reassurance available.“While many of the powers regarding EU citizens are reserved to Westminster, we will do all we can to help those living here in the North-East.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: new handbook aims to help local playgroups
story: The task of running a community based playgroup will be made easier for local groups with the publication of a free guide giving invaluable information and advice on managing their affairs smoothly.The guide, ‘Partnership for Success: a Committee Handbook’, has been prepared and published by Aberdeenshire Council and the charity Early Years Scotland, and will be launched at the Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie on Tuesday, March .The voluntary committees in charge of community playgroups can often feel overwhelmed by the demands and responsibilities of employing staff and keeping their group afloat, so the handbook is intended to help support them and enable a smooth handover for future committees.A copy of the handbook will be distributed to every playgroup in Aberdeenshire.Many of the playgroups are Early Learning and Childcarefunded providers for the local authority, and will have a vital role to play when the number of funded ELC hours parents can access for their child is doubled to , next year.The launch will bring together committee members and employees from local playgroups, alongside representatives from Aberdeenshire Council, Early Years Scotland, and local councillors.Speakers will include Jean Carwood-Edwards, Chief Executive, Early Years Scotland Laurence Findlay, Director of Education and Children’s Services, Aberdeenshire Council and Audrey Hendry, Lead Officer Education, Aberdeenshire Council.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Advice for supporters ahead of Scottish Cup game at Pittodrie viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: oldmeldrum publican loses 2am licencing bid
story: An Oldmeldrum publican believes others in the trade are #wasting their time# applying for a am drinks licence after a failed bid by his own premises.Robin Philip, owner of Morris’s Hotel, was unsuccessful in his application for an extra hour on a Friday and Saturday for his public bar in a bid to boost dwindling trade.Dficult trading times in an economic climate hampered by increases in business rates and operating costs had prompted his application to extend weekend drinking times.However Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board stuck to its policies which limits pubs and hotels to a am licence but which offers nightclubs am licences Sunday to Thursday and am on Fridays and Saturdays.The board had earlier heard objections to the later opening element of the application from Sgt Kim Wood on behalf of Police Scotland who said there was clear evidence that the longer and later on-sales licensed premises operate, the “higher the likelihood of incidents of crime, disorder and anti-social behaviour occurring”.But the Oldmeldrum publican stressed he had not experienced trouble in the  years he has run his business.He said the public bar only held  patrons who merely wanted to enjoy a slightly longer night out on a Saturday.Mr Philip said the crime figures presented by the police were for Ellon and Inverurie and had no bearing on Oldmeldrum.A motion by Cllr Marion Ewenson to approve elements of the application, including an outdoor drinking area, with the exception of the am Friday and Saturday extension, was unanimously approved.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: year of success for foveran business
story: A popular Foveran business celebrated its first anniversary last month.The Barn marked its first year of business on Friday, January .The cafe and beauty salonis owned by husband and we team Mark and Christine Graham.Since opening just one year ago the business has exceeded both their expectations as Christine explained: “We have been really busy and didn’t expect to be at this stage so early on.“We recently extended into the next building here and moved our kitchen so we have more seating for our customers and the potential for much more possibilities in the future.“We’ve added  extra seats but there are times where we could still do with more, and we have also created four new jobs.”She added: “We now have a team of  including two full-time chefs and two kitchen porters. A lot of our team members are also celebrating their first anniversary with us which is lovely.”Commenting on business so far, Christine believes their customers have been the key to its success as she said: “We’ve got an amazing following and the new AWPR has made a dference too as we have had customers up from as far as Stonehaven and Banchory.“We have -star reviews online and people have found us via TripAdvisor and Google.“The support has been overwhelming and we would be nothing without our customers, clients and team.”Looking to the future Christine said: “There are more exciting projects to come, but we are really excited about the warmer weather coming so people can enjoy a seat outside.”She added: “We recently received our licence so we are now open on Friday and Saturday evenings, people can stay a bit longer and enjoy a couple of drinks.“We are looking to organise comedy nights and race nights, and we are now fully licenced for private events including birthdays, weddings and christenings.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: Barn owl numbers recover
story: CAITHNESS is considered to have the most northerly population of barn owls in the world ndash and they have recovered well after severe winters took their toll on numbers eight or nine years ago, according to RSPB Scotland.Representatives of the nature conservation charity were saddened to discover recently that a fit and healthy barn owl had apparently been killed by a vehicle in the county, but on the whole the birds are said to be doing well.Barn owls originally evolved in warm, dry climates where food is in abundance all year round. It is therefore unsurprising that barn owls in the north of Scotland have a hard time during the winter months, with peak mortality rates being between December and March due to starvation.As temperatures start to drop in winter, small mammals become less active, meaning a lot less food is available for barn owls, and they need to work extra-hard to find it. This often results in the owls being forced to feed during daylight, even though they are naturally nocturnal hunters.This lack of food is particularly dangerous for barn owls as they are poorly insulated and need more food in winter to provide them with enough energy to stay warm.The Barn Owl Trust estimates that between  and  barn owls are killed each year on UK roads.RSPB Scotland site manager Dave Jones recently sent a deceased barn owl to the Scottish Agricultural College in Thurso for autopsy, when some concerned neighbours reported it after finding it at the roadside.The results of the autopsy showed that the bird was fit and healthy, "in good shape and hunting successfully", and that the death followed trauma to its wing and abdomen ndash suggesting that the bird died as a result of being hit by a vehicle.Dave said: "It is extremely sad to discover that a fit and healthy birds le ended in this way. The barn owls in Caithness really are at the edge of their natural comfort zone and are particularly vulnerable in winter, so it isnt an unusual result, unfortunately. Its not all doom and gloom, though. Although we still find some casualties in this way, our population of barn owls in Caithness has recovered from the particularly poor winters of   and  , and they are considered to be the most northerly population of barn owls in the world."While we cant control the weather, there are some things we can do to help. If putting up a nest box, please make sure it isnt placed close to any busy roads. If you see a road casualty and it is safe to do so, please stop and report the find to your local wildle officer and to the Barn Owl Trust. This is helpful in identying accident black spots and monitoring for environmental hazards and poisons, and potential wildle crime."Monday  Mar  : AM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Monday  Mar  : AM
